signal.name: GSettings::change-event
signal.description:
Emitted once per change event that affects this settings object.
You should connect to this signal only if you are interested in viewing groups of changes before they are split out into multiple emissions of the [signal@Gio.Settings::changed] signal. For most use cases it is more appropriate to use the [signal@Gio.Settings::changed] signal.
In the event that the change event applies to one or more specified keys, @keys will be an array of [alias@GLib.Quark]s of length @n_keys. In the event that the change event applies to the [class@Gio.Settings] object as a whole (ie: potentially every key has been changed) then @keys will be `NULL` and @n_keys will be `0`.
The default handler for this signal invokes the [signal@Gio.Settings::changed] signal for each affected key. If any other connected handler returns true then this default functionality will be suppressed.

parameter.name: settings
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: keys
parameter.parameter_description: array of the keys which have changed

parameter.name: n_keys
parameter.parameter_description: the length of the @keys array, or `0`

signal.return: true to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event, false to propagate the event further

signal.name: GSettings::changed
signal.description:
Emitted when a key has potentially changed.
You should call one of the [method@Gio.Settings.get] calls to check the new value.
This signal supports detailed connections. You can connect to the detailed signal `changed::x` in order to only receive callbacks when key `x` changes.
Note that @settings only emits this signal if you have read @key at least once while a signal handler was already connected for @key.

parameter.name: settings
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the key that changed

signal.name: GSettings::writable-change-event
signal.description:
Emitted once per writability change event that affects this settings object.
You should connect to this signal if you are interested in viewing groups of changes before they are split out into multiple emissions of the [signal@Gio.Settings::writable-changed] signal. For most use cases it is more appropriate to use the [signal@Gio.Settings::writable-changed] signal.
In the event that the writability change applies only to a single key, @key will be set to the [alias@GLib.Quark] for that key. In the event that the writability change affects the entire settings object, @key will be `0`.
The default handler for this signal invokes the [signal@Gio.Settings::writable-changed] and [signal@Gio.Settings::changed] signals for each affected key. This is done because changes in writability might also imply changes in value (if for example, a new mandatory setting is introduced). If any other connected handler returns true then this default functionality will be suppressed.

parameter.name: settings
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

parameter.name: key
parameter.parameter_description: the quark of the key, or `0`

signal.return: true to stop other handlers from being invoked for the event, false to propagate the event further

signal.name: GSettings::writable-changed
signal.description:
Emitted when the writability of a key has potentially changed.
You should call [method@Gio.Settings.is_writable] in order to determine the new status.
This signal supports detailed connections. You can connect to the detailed signal `writable-changed::x` in order to only receive callbacks when the writability of `x` changes.

parameter.name: settings
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal was emitted

property.name: GSettings:backend
property.description: The name of the context that the settings are stored in.

property.name: GSettings:delay-apply
property.description:
Whether the [class@Gio.Settings] object is in [‘delay-apply’ mode](class.Settings.html#delay-apply-mode).
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSettings:has-unapplied
property.description:
Whether the [class@Gio.Settings] object has outstanding changes.
These changes will be applied when [method@Gio.Settings.apply] is called.

property.name: GSettings:path
property.description: The path within the backend where the settings are stored.

property.name: GSettings:schema
property.description:
The name of the schema that describes the types of keys for this [class@Gio.Settings] object.
The type of this property is *not* [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema]. [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema] has only existed since version 2.32 and unfortunately this name was used in previous versions to refer to the schema ID rather than the schema itself. Take care to use the [property@Gio.Settings:settings-schema] property if you wish to pass in a [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema].
Deprecated:2.32:Use the [property@Gio.Settings:schema-id] property instead. In a future version, this property may instead refer to a [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema].

property.name: GSettings:schema-id
property.description: The name of the schema that describes the types of keys for this [class@Gio.Settings] object.

property.name: GSettings:settings-schema
property.description:
The [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema] describing the types of keys for this [class@Gio.Settings] object.
Ideally, this property would be called [property@Gio.Settings:schema]. [struct@Gio.SettingsSchema] has only existed since version 2.32, however, and before then the [property@Gio.Settings:schema] property was used to refer to the ID of the schema rather than the schema itself. Take care.

enum.name: GSettingsBindFlags
enum.description:
Flags used when creating a binding.
These flags determine in which direction the binding works. The default is to synchronize in both directions.

parameter.name: G_SETTINGS_BIND_GET
parameter.parameter_description: Update the [class@GObject.Object] property when the setting changes. It is an error to use this flag if the property is not writable.

parameter.name: G_SETTINGS_BIND_SET
parameter.parameter_description: Update the setting when the [class@GObject.Object] property changes. It is an error to use this flag if the property is not readable.

parameter.name: G_SETTINGS_BIND_NO_SENSITIVITY
parameter.parameter_description: Do not try to bind a ‘sensitivity’ property to the writability of the setting

parameter.name: G_SETTINGS_BIND_GET_NO_CHANGES
parameter.parameter_description: When set in addition to [flags@Gio.SettingsBindFlags.GET], set the [class@GObject.Object] property value initially from the setting, but do not listen for changes of the setting

parameter.name: G_SETTINGS_BIND_INVERT_BOOLEAN
parameter.parameter_description: When passed to [method@Gio.Settings.bind], uses a pair of mapping functions that invert the boolean value when mapping between the setting and the property. The setting and property must both be booleans. You cannot pass this flag to [method@Gio.Settings.bind_with_mapping].

signal.name: GSimpleAction::activate
signal.description:
Indicates that the action was just activated.
@parameter will always be of the expected type, i.e. the parameter type specified when the action was created. If an incorrect type is given when activating the action, this signal is not emitted.
Since GLib 2.40, if no handler is connected to this signal then the default behaviour for boolean-stated actions with a %NULL parameter type is to toggle them via the #GSimpleAction::change-state signal. For stateful actions where the state type is equal to the parameter type, the default is to forward them directly to #GSimpleAction::change-state. This should allow almost all users of #GSimpleAction to connect only one handler or the other.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: parameter
parameter.parameter_description: the parameter to the activation, or %NULL if it has no parameter

signal.name: GSimpleAction::change-state

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: the requested value for the state

property.name: GSimpleAction:enabled
property.description:
If @action is currently enabled.
If the action is disabled then calls to g_action_activate() and g_action_change_state() have no effect.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSimpleAction:name
property.description:
The name of the action. This is mostly meaningful for identifying the action once it has been added to a #GSimpleActionGroup.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSimpleAction:parameter-type
property.description:
The type of the parameter that must be given when activating the action.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSimpleAction:state
property.description:
The state of the action, or %NULL if the action is stateless.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSimpleAction:state-type
property.description:
The #GVariantType of the state that the action has, or %NULL if the action is stateless.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GSimpleIOStream:input-stream
property.description:
The [class@Gio.InputStream] to read from.
Since: 2.44

property.name: GSimpleIOStream:output-stream
property.description:
The [class@Gio.OutputStream] to write to.
Since: 2.44

property.name: GSimpleProxyResolver:default-proxy
property.description:
The default proxy URI that will be used for any URI that doesn't match #GSimpleProxyResolver:ignore-hosts, and doesn't match any of the schemes set with g_simple_proxy_resolver_set_uri_proxy().
Note that as a special case, if this URI starts with "socks://", #GSimpleProxyResolver will treat it as referring to all three of the socks5, socks4a, and socks4 proxy types.

property.name: GSimpleProxyResolver:ignore-hosts
property.description:
A list of hostnames and IP addresses that the resolver should allow direct connections to.
Entries can be in one of 4 formats:
- A hostname, such as "example.com", ".example.com", or "*.example.com", any of which match "example.com" or any subdomain of it.
- An IPv4 or IPv6 address, such as "192.168.1.1", which matches only that address.
- A hostname or IP address followed by a port, such as "example.com:80", which matches whatever the hostname or IP address would match, but only for URLs with the (explicitly) indicated port. In the case of an IPv6 address, the address part must appear in brackets: "[::1]:443"
- An IP address range, given by a base address and prefix length, such as "fe80::/10", which matches any address in that range.
Note that when dealing with Unicode hostnames, the matching is done against the ASCII form of the name.
Also note that hostname exclusions apply only to connections made to hosts identified by name, and IP address exclusions apply only to connections made to hosts identified by address. That is, if example.com has an address of 192.168.1.1, and the :ignore-hosts list contains only "192.168.1.1", then a connection to "example.com" (eg, via a #GNetworkAddress) will use the proxy, and a connection to "192.168.1.1" (eg, via a #GInetSocketAddress) will not.
These rules match the "ignore-hosts"/"noproxy" rules most commonly used by other applications.

property.name: GSocket:blocking
property.description:
Whether I/O on this socket is blocking.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:broadcast
property.description:
Whether the socket should allow sending to broadcast addresses.
Since: 2.32

property.name: GSocket:family
property.description:
The socket’s address family.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:fd
property.description:
The socket’s file descriptor.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:keepalive
property.description:
Whether to keep the connection alive by sending periodic pings.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:listen-backlog
property.description:
The number of outstanding connections in the listen queue.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:local-address
property.description:
The local address the socket is bound to.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:multicast-loopback
property.description:
Whether outgoing multicast packets loop back to the local host.
Since: 2.32

property.name: GSocket:multicast-ttl
property.description:
Time-to-live out outgoing multicast packets
Since: 2.32

property.name: GSocket:protocol
property.description:
The ID of the protocol to use, or `-1` for unknown.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:remote-address
property.description:
The remote address the socket is connected to.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocket:timeout
property.description:
The timeout in seconds on socket I/O
Since: 2.26

property.name: GSocket:ttl
property.description:
Time-to-live for outgoing unicast packets
Since: 2.32

property.name: GSocket:type
property.description:
The socket’s type.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketAddress:family
property.description:
The family of the socket address.
Since: 2.22

signal.name: GSocketClient::event
signal.description:
Emitted when @client's activity on @connectable changes state. Among other things, this can be used to provide progress information about a network connection in the UI. The meanings of the different @event values are as follows:
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_RESOLVING: @client is about to look up @connectable in DNS. @connection will be %NULL.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_RESOLVED: @client has successfully resolved @connectable in DNS. @connection will be %NULL.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_CONNECTING: @client is about to make a connection to a remote host; either a proxy server or the destination server itself. @connection is the #GSocketConnection, which is not yet connected. Since GLib 2.40, you can access the remote address via g_socket_connection_get_remote_address().
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_CONNECTED: @client has successfully connected to a remote host. @connection is the connected #GSocketConnection.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_PROXY_NEGOTIATING: @client is about to negotiate with a proxy to get it to connect to @connectable. @connection is the #GSocketConnection to the proxy server.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_PROXY_NEGOTIATED: @client has negotiated a connection to @connectable through a proxy server. @connection is the stream returned from g_proxy_connect(), which may or may not be a #GSocketConnection.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_TLS_HANDSHAKING: @client is about to begin a TLS handshake. @connection is a #GTlsClientConnection.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_TLS_HANDSHAKED: @client has successfully completed the TLS handshake. @connection is a #GTlsClientConnection.
- %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_COMPLETE: @client has either successfully connected to @connectable (in which case @connection is the #GSocketConnection that it will be returning to the caller) or has failed (in which case @connection is %NULL and the client is about to return an error).
Each event except %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_COMPLETE may be emitted multiple times (or not at all) for a given connectable (in particular, if @client ends up attempting to connect to more than one address). However, if @client emits the #GSocketClient::event signal at all for a given connectable, then it will always emit it with %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_COMPLETE when it is done.
Note that there may be additional #GSocketClientEvent values in the future; unrecognized @event values should be ignored.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: connection
parameter.parameter_description: the current representation of the connection

property.name: GSocketClient:enable-proxy
property.description:
Enable proxy support.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:family
property.description:
The address family to use for socket construction.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:local-address
property.description:
The local address constructed sockets will be bound to.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:protocol
property.description:
The protocol to use for socket construction, or `0` for default.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:proxy-resolver
property.description:
The proxy resolver to use
Since: 2.36

property.name: GSocketClient:timeout
property.description:
The I/O timeout for sockets, in seconds, or `0` for none.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:tls
property.description:
Whether to create TLS connections.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GSocketClient:tls-validation-flags
property.description:
The TLS validation flags used when creating TLS connections. The default value is %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_VALIDATE_ALL.
GLib guarantees that if certificate verification fails, at least one flag will be set, but it does not guarantee that all possible flags will be set. Accordingly, you may not safely decide to ignore any particular type of error. For example, it would be incorrect to mask %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED if you want to allow expired certificates, because this could potentially be the only error flag set even if other problems exist with the certificate. Therefore, there is no safe way to use this property. This is not a horrible problem, though, because you should not be attempting to ignore validation errors anyway. If you really must ignore TLS certificate errors, connect to the #GSocketClient::event signal, wait for it to be emitted with %G_SOCKET_CLIENT_TLS_HANDSHAKING, and use that to connect to #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate.
Deprecated: 2.72: Do not attempt to ignore validation errors.

property.name: GSocketClient:type
property.description:
The type to use for socket construction.
Since: 2.22

enum.name: GSocketClientEvent
enum.description:
Describes an event occurring on a #GSocketClient. See the #GSocketClient::event signal for more details.
Additional values may be added to this type in the future.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_RESOLVING
parameter.parameter_description: The client is doing a DNS lookup.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_RESOLVED
parameter.parameter_description: The client has completed a DNS lookup.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_CONNECTING
parameter.parameter_description: The client is connecting to a remote host (either a proxy or the destination server).

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_CONNECTED
parameter.parameter_description: The client has connected to a remote host.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_PROXY_NEGOTIATING
parameter.parameter_description: The client is negotiating with a proxy to connect to the destination server.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_PROXY_NEGOTIATED
parameter.parameter_description: The client has negotiated with the proxy server.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_TLS_HANDSHAKING
parameter.parameter_description: The client is performing a TLS handshake.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_TLS_HANDSHAKED
parameter.parameter_description: The client has performed a TLS handshake.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_CLIENT_COMPLETE
parameter.parameter_description: The client is done with a particular #GSocketConnectable.

property.name: GSocketConnection:socket
property.description:
The underlying [class@Gio.Socket].
Since: 2.22

enum.name: GSocketFamily
enum.description:
The protocol family of a #GSocketAddress. (These values are identical to the system defines %AF_INET, %AF_INET6 and %AF_UNIX, if available.)
Since: 2.22

signal.name: GSocketListener::event
signal.description:
Emitted when @listener's activity on @socket changes state. Note that when @listener is used to listen on both IPv4 and IPv6, a separate set of signals will be emitted for each, and the order they happen in is undefined.
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: socket
parameter.parameter_description: the #GSocket the event is occurring on

property.name: GSocketListener:listen-backlog
property.description:
The number of outstanding connections in the listen queue.
Since: 2.22

enum.name: GSocketListenerEvent
enum.description:
Describes an event occurring on a #GSocketListener. See the #GSocketListener::event signal for more details.
Additional values may be added to this type in the future.
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_LISTENER_BINDING
parameter.parameter_description: The listener is about to bind a socket.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_LISTENER_BOUND
parameter.parameter_description: The listener has bound a socket.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_LISTENER_LISTENING
parameter.parameter_description: The listener is about to start listening on this socket.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_LISTENER_LISTENED
parameter.parameter_description: The listener is now listening on this socket.

enum.name: GSocketMsgFlags
enum.description:
Flags used in g_socket_receive_message() and g_socket_send_message(). The flags listed in the enum are some commonly available flags, but the values used for them are the same as on the platform, and any other flags are passed in/out as is. So to use a platform specific flag, just include the right system header and pass in the flag.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_MSG_OOB
parameter.parameter_description: Request to send/receive out of band data.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_MSG_PEEK
parameter.parameter_description: Read data from the socket without removing it from the queue.

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_MSG_DONTROUTE
parameter.parameter_description: Don't use a gateway to send out the packet, only send to hosts on directly connected networks.

enum.name: GSocketProtocol
enum.description:
A protocol identifier is specified when creating a #GSocket, which is a family/type specific identifier, where 0 means the default protocol for the particular family/type.
This enum contains a set of commonly available and used protocols. You can also pass any other identifiers handled by the platform in order to use protocols not listed here.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_PROTOCOL_DEFAULT
parameter.parameter_description: The default protocol for the family/type

signal.name: GSocketService::incoming
signal.return: %TRUE to stop other handlers from being called

property.name: GSocketService:active
property.description:
Whether the service is currently accepting connections.
Since: 2.46

enum.name: GSocketType
enum.description:
Flags used when creating a #GSocket. Some protocols may not implement all the socket types.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: G_SOCKET_TYPE_SEQPACKET
parameter.parameter_description: Reliable connection-based passing of datagrams of fixed maximum length (e.g. SCTP).

property.name: GSubprocess:argv
property.description:
Argument vector.
Since: 2.40

property.name: GSubprocess:flags
property.description:
Subprocess flags.
Since: 2.40

enum.name: GSubprocessFlags
enum.description:
Flags to define the behaviour of a #GSubprocess.
Note that the default for stdin is to redirect from `/dev/null`. For stdout and stderr the default are for them to inherit the corresponding descriptor from the calling process.
Note that it is a programmer error to mix 'incompatible' flags. For example, you may not request both %G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDOUT_PIPE and %G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDOUT_SILENCE.
Since: 2.40

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDIN_PIPE
parameter.parameter_description: create a pipe for the stdin of the spawned process that can be accessed with g_subprocess_get_stdin_pipe().

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDIN_INHERIT
parameter.parameter_description: stdin is inherited from the calling process.

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDOUT_PIPE
parameter.parameter_description: create a pipe for the stdout of the spawned process that can be accessed with g_subprocess_get_stdout_pipe().

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDOUT_SILENCE
parameter.parameter_description: silence the stdout of the spawned process (ie: redirect to `/dev/null`).

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDERR_PIPE
parameter.parameter_description: create a pipe for the stderr of the spawned process that can be accessed with g_subprocess_get_stderr_pipe().

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDERR_SILENCE
parameter.parameter_description: silence the stderr of the spawned process (ie: redirect to `/dev/null`).

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_STDERR_MERGE
parameter.parameter_description: merge the stderr of the spawned process with whatever the stdout happens to be. This is a good way of directing both streams to a common log file, for example.

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_INHERIT_FDS
parameter.parameter_description: spawned processes will inherit the file descriptors of their parent, unless those descriptors have been explicitly marked as close-on-exec. This flag has no effect over the "standard" file descriptors (stdin, stdout, stderr).

parameter.name: G_SUBPROCESS_FLAGS_SEARCH_PATH_FROM_ENVP
parameter.parameter_description: if path searching is needed when spawning the subprocess, use the `PATH` in the launcher environment. (Since: 2.72)

property.name: GSubprocessLauncher:flags
property.description:
[flags@Gio.SubprocessFlags] for launched processes.
Since: 2.40

property.name: GTask:completed
property.description:
Whether the task has completed, meaning its callback (if set) has been invoked.
This can only happen after g_task_return_pointer(), g_task_return_error() or one of the other return functions have been called on the task. However, it is not guaranteed to happen immediately after those functions are called, as the task’s callback may need to be scheduled to run in a different thread.
That means it is **not safe** to use this property to track whether a return function has been called on the #GTask. Callers must do that tracking themselves, typically by linking the lifetime of the #GTask to the control flow of their code.
This property is guaranteed to change from %FALSE to %TRUE exactly once.
The #GObject::notify signal for this change is emitted in the same main context as the task’s callback, immediately after that callback is invoked.
Since: 2.44

property.name: GTcpConnection:graceful-disconnect
property.description:
Whether [method@Gio.IOStream.close] does a graceful disconnect.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GTcpWrapperConnection:base-io-stream
property.description:
The wrapped [class@Gio.IOStream].
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTestDBus:flags
property.description:
#GTestDBusFlags specifying the behaviour of the D-Bus session.
Since: 2.34

enum.name: GTestDBusFlags
enum.description:
Flags to define future #GTestDBus behaviour.
Since: 2.34

property.name: GThemedIcon:name
property.description: The icon name.

property.name: GThemedIcon:names
property.description: A %NULL-terminated array of icon names.

property.name: GThemedIcon:use-default-fallbacks
property.description:
Whether to use the default fallbacks found by shortening the icon name at '-' characters. If the "names" array has more than one element, ignores any past the first.
For example, if the icon name was "gnome-dev-cdrom-audio", the array would become |[<!-- language="C" --> { "gnome-dev-cdrom-audio", "gnome-dev-cdrom", "gnome-dev", "gnome", NULL }; ]|

signal.name: GThreadedSocketService::run
signal.description: The ::run signal is emitted in a worker thread in response to an incoming connection. This thread is dedicated to handling @connection and may perform blocking IO. The signal handler need not return until the connection is closed.
signal.return: %TRUE to stop further signal handlers from being called

property.name: GThreadedSocketService:max-threads
property.description:
The maximum number of threads handling clients for this service.
Since: 2.22

enum.name: GTlsAuthenticationMode
enum.description:
The client authentication mode for a #GTlsServerConnection.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:certificate
property.description:
The DER (binary) encoded representation of the certificate. This property and the #GTlsCertificate:certificate-pem property represent the same data, just in different forms.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:certificate-pem
property.description:
The PEM (ASCII) encoded representation of the certificate. This property and the #GTlsCertificate:certificate property represent the same data, just in different forms.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:dns-names
property.description:
The DNS names from the certificate's Subject Alternative Names (SANs), %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsCertificate:ip-addresses
property.description:
The IP addresses from the certificate's Subject Alternative Names (SANs), %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsCertificate:issuer
property.description:
A #GTlsCertificate representing the entity that issued this certificate. If %NULL, this means that the certificate is either self-signed, or else the certificate of the issuer is not available.
Beware the issuer certificate may not be the same as the certificate that would actually be used to construct a valid certification path during certificate verification. [RFC 4158](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4158) explains why an issuer certificate cannot be naively assumed to be part of the the certification path (though GLib's TLS backends may not follow the path building strategies outlined in this RFC). Due to the complexity of certification path building, GLib does not provide any way to know which certification path will actually be used. Accordingly, this property cannot be used to make security-related decisions. Only GLib itself should make security decisions about TLS certificates.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:issuer-name
property.description:
The issuer from the certificate, %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsCertificate:not-valid-after
property.description:
The time at which this cert is no longer valid, %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsCertificate:not-valid-before
property.description:
The time at which this cert is considered to be valid, %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsCertificate:password
property.description:
An optional password used when constructed with GTlsCertificate:pkcs12-data.
Since: 2.72

property.name: GTlsCertificate:pkcs11-uri
property.description:
A URI referencing the [PKCS \#11](https://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-base/v3.0/os/pkcs11-base-v3.0-os.html) objects containing an X.509 certificate and optionally a private key.
If %NULL, the certificate is either not backed by PKCS \#11 or the #GTlsBackend does not support PKCS \#11.
Since: 2.68

property.name: GTlsCertificate:pkcs12-data
property.description:
The PKCS #12 formatted data used to construct the object.
See also: g_tls_certificate_new_from_pkcs12()
Since: 2.72

property.name: GTlsCertificate:private-key
property.description:
The DER (binary) encoded representation of the certificate's private key, in either [PKCS \#1 format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8017) or unencrypted [PKCS \#8 format.](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5208) PKCS \#8 format is supported since 2.32; earlier releases only support PKCS \#1. You can use the `openssl rsa` tool to convert PKCS \#8 keys to PKCS \#1.
This property (or the #GTlsCertificate:private-key-pem property) can be set when constructing a key (for example, from a file). Since GLib 2.70, it is now also readable; however, be aware that if the private key is backed by a PKCS \#11 URI – for example, if it is stored on a smartcard – then this property will be %NULL. If so, the private key must be referenced via its PKCS \#11 URI, #GTlsCertificate:private-key-pkcs11-uri. You must check both properties to see if the certificate really has a private key. When this property is read, the output format will be unencrypted PKCS \#8.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:private-key-pem
property.description:
The PEM (ASCII) encoded representation of the certificate's private key in either [PKCS \#1 format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8017) ("`BEGIN RSA PRIVATE KEY`") or unencrypted [PKCS \#8 format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5208) ("`BEGIN PRIVATE KEY`"). PKCS \#8 format is supported since 2.32; earlier releases only support PKCS \#1. You can use the `openssl rsa` tool to convert PKCS \#8 keys to PKCS \#1.
This property (or the #GTlsCertificate:private-key property) can be set when constructing a key (for example, from a file). Since GLib 2.70, it is now also readable; however, be aware that if the private key is backed by a PKCS \#11 URI - for example, if it is stored on a smartcard - then this property will be %NULL. If so, the private key must be referenced via its PKCS \#11 URI, #GTlsCertificate:private-key-pkcs11-uri. You must check both properties to see if the certificate really has a private key. When this property is read, the output format will be unencrypted PKCS \#8.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsCertificate:private-key-pkcs11-uri
property.description:
A URI referencing a [PKCS \#11](https://docs.oasis-open.org/pkcs11/pkcs11-base/v3.0/os/pkcs11-base-v3.0-os.html) object containing a private key.
Since: 2.68

property.name: GTlsCertificate:subject-name
property.description:
The subject from the cert, %NULL if unavailable.
Since: 2.70

enum.name: GTlsCertificateFlags
enum.description:
A set of flags describing TLS certification validation. This can be used to describe why a particular certificate was rejected (for example, in #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate).
GLib guarantees that if certificate verification fails, at least one flag will be set, but it does not guarantee that all possible flags will be set. Accordingly, you may not safely decide to ignore any particular type of error. For example, it would be incorrect to mask %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED if you want to allow expired certificates, because this could potentially be the only error flag set even if other problems exist with the certificate.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN_CA
parameter.parameter_description: The signing certificate authority is not known.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_BAD_IDENTITY
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate does not match the expected identity of the site that it was retrieved from.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_NOT_ACTIVATED
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate's activation time is still in the future

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_REVOKED
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate has been revoked according to the #GTlsConnection's certificate revocation list.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_INSECURE
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate's algorithm is considered insecure.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_GENERIC_ERROR
parameter.parameter_description: Some other error occurred validating the certificate

parameter.name: G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_VALIDATE_ALL
parameter.parameter_description: the combination of all of the above flags

enum.name: GTlsCertificateRequestFlags
enum.description:
Flags for g_tls_interaction_request_certificate(), g_tls_interaction_request_certificate_async(), and g_tls_interaction_invoke_request_certificate().
Since: 2.40

enum.name: GTlsChannelBindingError
enum.description:
An error code used with %G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR in a #GError to indicate a TLS channel binding retrieval error.
Since: 2.66

parameter.name: G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED
parameter.parameter_description: Either entire binding retrieval facility or specific binding type is not implemented in the TLS backend.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR_INVALID_STATE
parameter.parameter_description: The handshake is not yet complete on the connection which is a strong requirement for any existing binding type.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR_NOT_AVAILABLE
parameter.parameter_description: Handshake is complete but binding data is not available. That normally indicates the TLS implementation failed to provide the binding data. For example, some implementations do not provide a peer certificate for resumed connections.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR_NOT_SUPPORTED
parameter.parameter_description: Binding type is not supported on the current connection. This error could be triggered when requesting `tls-server-end-point` binding data for a certificate which has no hash function or uses multiple hash functions.

parameter.name: G_TLS_CHANNEL_BINDING_ERROR_GENERAL_ERROR
parameter.parameter_description: Any other backend error preventing binding data retrieval.

enum.name: GTlsChannelBindingType
enum.description:
The type of TLS channel binding data to retrieve from #GTlsConnection or #GDtlsConnection, as documented by RFC 5929 or RFC 9266. The [`tls-unique-for-telnet`](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5929#section-5) binding type is not currently implemented.
Since: 2.66

property.name: GTlsClientConnection:accepted-cas
property.description:
A list of the distinguished names of the Certificate Authorities that the server will accept client certificates signed by. If the server requests a client certificate during the handshake, then this property will be set after the handshake completes.
Each item in the list is a #GByteArray which contains the complete subject DN of the certificate authority.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsClientConnection:server-identity
property.description:
A #GSocketConnectable describing the identity of the server that is expected on the other end of the connection.
If the %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_BAD_IDENTITY flag is set in #GTlsClientConnection:validation-flags, this object will be used to determine the expected identify of the remote end of the connection; if #GTlsClientConnection:server-identity is not set, or does not match the identity presented by the server, then the %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_BAD_IDENTITY validation will fail.
In addition to its use in verifying the server certificate, this is also used to give a hint to the server about what certificate we expect, which is useful for servers that serve virtual hosts.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsClientConnection:use-ssl3
property.description:
SSL 3.0 is no longer supported. See g_tls_client_connection_set_use_ssl3() for details.
Since: 2.28
Deprecated: 2.56: SSL 3.0 is insecure.

property.name: GTlsClientConnection:validation-flags
property.description:
What steps to perform when validating a certificate received from a server. Server certificates that fail to validate in any of the ways indicated here will be rejected unless the application overrides the default via #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate.
GLib guarantees that if certificate verification fails, at least one flag will be set, but it does not guarantee that all possible flags will be set. Accordingly, you may not safely decide to ignore any particular type of error. For example, it would be incorrect to mask %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED if you want to allow expired certificates, because this could potentially be the only error flag set even if other problems exist with the certificate. Therefore, there is no safe way to use this property. This is not a horrible problem, though, because you should not be attempting to ignore validation errors anyway. If you really must ignore TLS certificate errors, connect to #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate.
Since: 2.28
Deprecated: 2.72: Do not attempt to ignore validation errors.

signal.name: GTlsConnection::accept-certificate
signal.description:
Emitted during the TLS handshake after the peer certificate has been received. You can examine @peer_cert's certification path by calling g_tls_certificate_get_issuer() on it.
For a client-side connection, @peer_cert is the server's certificate, and the signal will only be emitted if the certificate was not acceptable according to @conn's #GTlsClientConnection:validation_flags. If you would like the certificate to be accepted despite @errors, return %TRUE from the signal handler. Otherwise, if no handler accepts the certificate, the handshake will fail with %G_TLS_ERROR_BAD_CERTIFICATE.
GLib guarantees that if certificate verification fails, this signal will be emitted with at least one error will be set in @errors, but it does not guarantee that all possible errors will be set. Accordingly, you may not safely decide to ignore any particular type of error. For example, it would be incorrect to ignore %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED if you want to allow expired certificates, because this could potentially be the only error flag set even if other problems exist with the certificate.
For a server-side connection, @peer_cert is the certificate presented by the client, if this was requested via the server's #GTlsServerConnection:authentication_mode. On the server side, the signal is always emitted when the client presents a certificate, and the certificate will only be accepted if a handler returns %TRUE.
Note that if this signal is emitted as part of asynchronous I/O in the main thread, then you should not attempt to interact with the user before returning from the signal handler. If you want to let the user decide whether or not to accept the certificate, you would have to return %FALSE from the signal handler on the first attempt, and then after the connection attempt returns a %G_TLS_ERROR_BAD_CERTIFICATE, you can interact with the user, and if the user decides to accept the certificate, remember that fact, create a new connection, and return %TRUE from the signal handler the next time.
If you are doing I/O in another thread, you do not need to worry about this, and can simply block in the signal handler until the UI thread returns an answer.
Since: 2.28
signal.return: %TRUE to accept @peer_cert (which will also immediately end the signal emission). %FALSE to allow the signal emission to continue, which will cause the handshake to fail if no one else overrides it.

property.name: GTlsConnection:advertised-protocols
property.description:
The list of application-layer protocols that the connection advertises that it is willing to speak. See g_tls_connection_set_advertised_protocols().
Since: 2.60

property.name: GTlsConnection:base-io-stream
property.description:
The #GIOStream that the connection wraps. The connection holds a reference to this stream, and may run operations on the stream from other threads throughout its lifetime. Consequently, after the #GIOStream has been constructed, application code may only run its own operations on this stream when no #GIOStream operations are running.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsConnection:certificate
property.description:
The connection's certificate; see g_tls_connection_set_certificate().
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsConnection:ciphersuite-name
property.description:
The name of the TLS ciphersuite in use. See g_tls_connection_get_ciphersuite_name().
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsConnection:database
property.description:
The certificate database to use when verifying this TLS connection. If no certificate database is set, then the default database will be used. See g_tls_backend_get_default_database().
When using a non-default database, #GTlsConnection must fall back to using the #GTlsDatabase to perform certificate verification using g_tls_database_verify_chain(), which means certificate verification will not be able to make use of TLS session context. This may be less secure. For example, if you create your own #GTlsDatabase that just wraps the default #GTlsDatabase, you might expect that you have not changed anything, but this is not true because you may have altered the behavior of #GTlsConnection by causing it to use g_tls_database_verify_chain(). See the documentation of g_tls_database_verify_chain() for more details on specific security checks that may not be performed. Accordingly, setting a non-default database is discouraged except for specialty applications with unusual security requirements.
Since: 2.30

property.name: GTlsConnection:interaction
property.description:
A #GTlsInteraction object to be used when the connection or certificate database need to interact with the user. This will be used to prompt the user for passwords where necessary.
Since: 2.30

property.name: GTlsConnection:negotiated-protocol
property.description:
The application-layer protocol negotiated during the TLS handshake. See g_tls_connection_get_negotiated_protocol().
Since: 2.60

property.name: GTlsConnection:peer-certificate
property.description:
The connection's peer's certificate, after the TLS handshake has completed or failed. Note in particular that this is not yet set during the emission of #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate.
(You can watch for a #GObject::notify signal on this property to detect when a handshake has occurred.)
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsConnection:peer-certificate-errors
property.description:
The errors noticed while verifying #GTlsConnection:peer-certificate. Normally this should be 0, but it may not be if #GTlsClientConnection:validation-flags is not %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_VALIDATE_ALL, or if #GTlsConnection::accept-certificate overrode the default behavior.
GLib guarantees that if certificate verification fails, at least one error will be set, but it does not guarantee that all possible errors will be set. Accordingly, you may not safely decide to ignore any particular type of error. For example, it would be incorrect to mask %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_EXPIRED if you want to allow expired certificates, because this could potentially be the only error flag set even if other problems exist with the certificate.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsConnection:protocol-version
property.description:
The TLS protocol version in use. See g_tls_connection_get_protocol_version().
Since: 2.70

property.name: GTlsConnection:rehandshake-mode
property.description:
The rehandshaking mode. See g_tls_connection_set_rehandshake_mode().
Since: 2.28
Deprecated: 2.60: The rehandshake mode is ignored.

property.name: GTlsConnection:require-close-notify
property.description:
Whether or not proper TLS close notification is required. See g_tls_connection_set_require_close_notify().
Since: 2.28

property.name: GTlsConnection:use-system-certdb
property.description:
Whether or not the system certificate database will be used to verify peer certificates. See g_tls_connection_set_use_system_certdb().
Deprecated: 2.30: Use GTlsConnection:database instead

enum.name: GTlsDatabaseLookupFlags
enum.description:
Flags for g_tls_database_lookup_certificate_for_handle(), g_tls_database_lookup_certificate_issuer(), and g_tls_database_lookup_certificates_issued_by().
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: G_TLS_DATABASE_LOOKUP_KEYPAIR
parameter.parameter_description: Restrict lookup to certificates that have a private key.

enum.name: GTlsDatabaseVerifyFlags
enum.description:
Flags for g_tls_database_verify_chain().
Since: 2.30

enum.name: GTlsError
enum.description:
An error code used with %G_TLS_ERROR in a #GError returned from a TLS-related routine.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_BAD_CERTIFICATE
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate presented could not be parsed or failed validation.

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_NOT_TLS
parameter.parameter_description: The TLS handshake failed because the peer does not seem to be a TLS server.

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_HANDSHAKE
parameter.parameter_description: The TLS handshake failed because the peer's certificate was not acceptable.

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_CERTIFICATE_REQUIRED
parameter.parameter_description: The TLS handshake failed because the server requested a client-side certificate, but none was provided. See g_tls_connection_set_certificate().

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_EOF
parameter.parameter_description: The TLS connection was closed without proper notice, which may indicate an attack. See g_tls_connection_set_require_close_notify().

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_INAPPROPRIATE_FALLBACK
parameter.parameter_description: The TLS handshake failed because the client sent the fallback SCSV, indicating a protocol downgrade attack. Since: 2.60

parameter.name: G_TLS_ERROR_BAD_CERTIFICATE_PASSWORD
parameter.parameter_description: The certificate failed to load because a password was incorrect. Since: 2.72

property.name: GTlsFileDatabase:anchors
property.description:
The path to a file containing PEM encoded certificate authority root anchors. The certificates in this file will be treated as root authorities for the purpose of verifying other certificates via the g_tls_database_verify_chain() operation.
Since: 2.30

enum.name: GTlsInteractionResult
enum.description:
#GTlsInteractionResult is returned by various functions in #GTlsInteraction when finishing an interaction request.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: G_TLS_INTERACTION_UNHANDLED
parameter.parameter_description: The interaction was unhandled (i.e. not implemented).

parameter.name: G_TLS_INTERACTION_HANDLED
parameter.parameter_description: The interaction completed, and resulting data is available.

parameter.name: G_TLS_INTERACTION_FAILED
parameter.parameter_description: The interaction has failed, or was cancelled. and the operation should be aborted.

property.name: GTlsPassword:description
property.description:
Description of what the password is for.
Since: 2.30

property.name: GTlsPassword:flags
property.description:
Flags about the password.
Since: 2.30

property.name: GTlsPassword:warning
property.description:
Warning about the password.
Since: 2.30

enum.name: GTlsPasswordFlags
enum.description:
Various flags for the password.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_RETRY
parameter.parameter_description: The password was wrong, and the user should retry.

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_MANY_TRIES
parameter.parameter_description: Hint to the user that the password has been wrong many times, and the user may not have many chances left.

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_FINAL_TRY
parameter.parameter_description: Hint to the user that this is the last try to get this password right.

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_PKCS11_USER
parameter.parameter_description: For PKCS #11, the user PIN is required. Since: 2.70.

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_PKCS11_SECURITY_OFFICER
parameter.parameter_description: For PKCS #11, the security officer PIN is required. Since: 2.70.

parameter.name: G_TLS_PASSWORD_PKCS11_CONTEXT_SPECIFIC
parameter.parameter_description: For PKCS #11, the context-specific PIN is required. Since: 2.70.

enum.name: GTlsProtocolVersion
enum.description:
The TLS or DTLS protocol version used by a #GTlsConnection or #GDtlsConnection. The integer values of these versions are sequential to ensure newer known protocol versions compare greater than older known versions. Any known DTLS protocol version will compare greater than any SSL or TLS protocol version. The protocol version may be %G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_UNKNOWN if the TLS backend supports a newer protocol version that GLib does not yet know about. This means that it's possible for an unknown DTLS protocol version to compare less than the TLS protocol versions.
Since: 2.70

parameter.name: G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_UNKNOWN
parameter.parameter_description: No protocol version or unknown protocol version

parameter.name: G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_SSL_3_0
parameter.parameter_description: SSL 3.0, which is insecure and should not be used

parameter.name: G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_TLS_1_0
parameter.parameter_description: TLS 1.0, which is insecure and should not be used

parameter.name: G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_TLS_1_1
parameter.parameter_description: TLS 1.1, which is insecure and should not be used

parameter.name: G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_DTLS_1_0
parameter.parameter_description: DTLS 1.0, which is insecure and should not be used

enum.name: GTlsRehandshakeMode
enum.description:
When to allow rehandshaking. See g_tls_connection_set_rehandshake_mode().
Since: 2.28
Deprecated: 2.60. Changing the rehandshake mode is no longer required for compatibility. Also, rehandshaking has been removed from the TLS protocol in TLS 1.3.

property.name: GTlsServerConnection:authentication-mode
property.description:
The #GTlsAuthenticationMode for the server. This can be changed before calling g_tls_connection_handshake() if you want to rehandshake with a different mode from the initial handshake.
Since: 2.28

property.name: GUnixCredentialsMessage:credentials
property.description:
The credentials stored in the message.
Since: 2.26

property.name: GUnixFDMessage:fd-list
property.description:
The [class@Gio.UnixFDList] object to send with the message.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GUnixInputStream:close-fd
property.description:
Whether to close the file descriptor when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20

property.name: GUnixInputStream:fd
property.description:
The file descriptor that the stream reads from.
Since: 2.20

signal.name: GUnixMountMonitor::mountpoints-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the Unix mount points have changed.

parameter.name: monitor
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

signal.name: GUnixMountMonitor::mounts-changed
signal.description: Emitted when the Unix mount entries have changed.

parameter.name: monitor
parameter.parameter_description: the object on which the signal is emitted

enum.name: GUnixMountType
enum.description: Types of Unix mounts.

parameter.name: G_UNIX_MOUNT_TYPE_NFS
parameter.parameter_description: Network File System (NFS) Unix mount type.

property.name: GUnixOutputStream:close-fd
property.description:
Whether to close the file descriptor when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20

property.name: GUnixOutputStream:fd
property.description:
The file descriptor that the stream writes to.
Since: 2.20

property.name: GUnixSocketAddress:abstract
property.description:
Whether or not this is an abstract address
Deprecated: Use #GUnixSocketAddress:address-type, which distinguishes between zero-padded and non-zero-padded abstract addresses.

property.name: GUnixSocketAddress:address-type
property.description:
The type of Unix socket address.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GUnixSocketAddress:path
property.description:
Unix socket path.
Since: 2.22

property.name: GUnixSocketAddress:path-as-array
property.description:
Unix socket path, as a byte array.
Since: 2.22

enum.name: GUnixSocketAddressType
enum.description:
The type of name used by a #GUnixSocketAddress. %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_PATH indicates a traditional unix domain socket bound to a filesystem path. %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ANONYMOUS indicates a socket not bound to any name (eg, a client-side socket, or a socket created with socketpair()).
For abstract sockets, there are two incompatible ways of naming them; the man pages suggest using the entire `struct sockaddr_un` as the name, padding the unused parts of the %sun_path field with zeroes; this corresponds to %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED. However, many programs instead just use a portion of %sun_path, and pass an appropriate smaller length to bind() or connect(). This is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED
parameter.parameter_description: an abstract name, 0-padded to the full length of a unix socket name

property.name: GWin32InputStream:close-handle
property.description:
Whether to close the file handle when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.26

property.name: GWin32InputStream:handle
property.description:
The handle that the stream reads from.
Since: 2.26

property.name: GWin32OutputStream:close-handle
property.description:
Whether to close the file handle when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.26

property.name: GWin32OutputStream:handle
property.description:
The file handle that the stream writes to.
Since: 2.26

property.name: GWin32RegistryKey:path
property.description:
A path to the key in the registry, in UTF-8.
Since: 2.46

property.name: GWin32RegistryKey:path-utf16
property.description:
A path to the key in the registry, in UTF-16.
Since: 2.46

property.name: GZlibCompressor:file-info
property.description:
A [class@Gio.FileInfo] containing file information to put into the gzip header.
The file name and modification time from the file info will be used.
This will only be used if non-`NULL` and [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:format] is [enum@Gio.ZlibCompressorFormat.GZIP].
Since: 2.26

property.name: GZlibCompressor:format
property.description:
The format of the compressed data.
Since: 2.24

property.name: GZlibCompressor:level
property.description:
The level of compression from `0` (no compression) to `9` (most compression).
`-1` for the default level.
Since: 2.24

property.name: GZlibCompressor:os
property.description:
The OS code of the gzip header.
This will be used if set to a non-negative value, and if [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:format] is [enum@Gio.ZlibCompressorFormat.GZIP], the compressor will set the OS code of the gzip header to this value.
If the value is unset, zlib will set the OS code depending on the platform. This may be undesirable when reproducible output is desired. In that case setting the OS code to `3` (for Unix) is recommended.
Since: 2.86

enum.name: GZlibCompressorFormat
enum.description:
Used to select the type of data format to use for #GZlibDecompressor and #GZlibCompressor.
Since: 2.24

property.name: GZlibDecompressor:file-info
property.description:
A [class@Gio.FileInfo] containing the information found in the gzip header of the data stream processed.
This will be `NULL` if the header was not yet fully processed, is not present at all, or the compressor’s [property@Gio.ZlibDecompressor:format] property is not [enum@Gio.ZlibCompressorFormat.GZIP].
Since: 2.26

property.name: GZlibDecompressor:format
property.description:
The format of the compressed data.
Since: 2.24

function.name: g_action_activate
function.description:
Activates the action.
@parameter must be the correct type of parameter for the action (ie: the parameter type given at construction time). If the parameter type was `NULL` then @parameter must also be `NULL`.
If the @parameter [type@GLib.Variant] is floating, it is consumed.
Since: 2.28

function.name: g_action_change_state
function.description:
Request for the state of @action to be changed to @value.
The action must be stateful and @value must be of the correct type. See [method@Gio.Action.get_state_type].
This call merely requests a change. The action may refuse to change its state or may change its state to something other than @value. See [method@Gio.Action.get_state_hint].
If the @value [type@GLib.Variant] is floating, it is consumed.
Since: 2.30

function.name: g_action_get_enabled
function.description:
Checks if @action is currently enabled.
An action must be enabled in order to be activated or in order to have its state changed from outside callers.
Since: 2.28
function.return: whether the action is enabled

function.name: g_action_get_name
function.description:
Queries the name of @action.
Since: 2.28
function.return: the name of the action

function.name: g_action_get_parameter_type
function.description:
Queries the type of the parameter that must be given when activating @action.
When activating the action using [method@Gio.Action.activate], the [type@GLib.Variant] given to that function must be of the type returned by this function.
In the case that this function returns `NULL`, you must not give any [type@GLib.Variant], but `NULL` instead.
Since: 2.28
function.return: the parameter type

function.name: g_action_get_state
function.description:
Queries the current state of @action.
If the action is not stateful then `NULL` will be returned. If the action is stateful then the type of the return value is the type given by [method@Gio.Action.get_state_type].
The return value (if non-`NULL`) should be freed with [method@GLib.Variant.unref] when it is no longer required.
Since: 2.28
function.return: the current state of the action

function.name: g_action_get_state_hint
function.description:
Requests a hint about the valid range of values for the state of @action.
If `NULL` is returned it either means that the action is not stateful or that there is no hint about the valid range of values for the state of the action.
If a [type@GLib.Variant] array is returned then each item in the array is a possible value for the state. If a [type@GLib.Variant] pair (ie: two-tuple) is returned then the tuple specifies the inclusive lower and upper bound of valid values for the state.
In any case, the information is merely a hint. It may be possible to have a state value outside of the hinted range and setting a value within the range may fail.
The return value (if non-`NULL`) should be freed with [method@GLib.Variant.unref] when it is no longer required.
Since: 2.28
function.return: the state range hint

function.name: g_action_get_state_type
function.description:
Queries the type of the state of @action.
If the action is stateful (e.g. created with [ctor@Gio.SimpleAction.new_stateful]) then this function returns the [type@GLib.VariantType] of the state. This is the type of the initial value given as the state. All calls to [method@Gio.Action.change_state] must give a [type@GLib.Variant] of this type and [method@Gio.Action.get_state] will return a [type@GLib.Variant] of the same type.
If the action is not stateful (e.g. created with [ctor@Gio.SimpleAction.new]) then this function will return `NULL`. In that case, [method@Gio.Action.get_state] will return `NULL` and you must not call [method@Gio.Action.change_state].
Since: 2.28
function.return: the state type, if the action is stateful

function.name: g_action_group_action_added
function.description:
Emits the [signal@Gio.ActionGroup::action-added] signal on @action_group.
This function should only be called by [type@Gio.ActionGroup] implementations.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an action in the group

function.name: g_action_group_action_enabled_changed
function.description:
Emits the [signal@Gio.ActionGroup::action-enabled-changed] signal on @action_group.
This function should only be called by [type@Gio.ActionGroup] implementations.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an action in the group

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.parameter_description: whether the action is now enabled

function.name: g_action_group_action_removed
function.description:
Emits the [signal@Gio.ActionGroup::action-removed] signal on @action_group.
This function should only be called by [type@Gio.ActionGroup] implementations.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an action in the group

function.name: g_action_group_action_state_changed
function.description:
Emits the [signal@Gio.ActionGroup::action-state-changed] signal on @action_group.
This function should only be called by [type@Gio.ActionGroup] implementations.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an action in the group

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the new state of the named action

function.name: g_action_group_activate_action

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to activate

function.name: g_action_group_change_action_state
function.description:
Request for the state of the named action within @action_group to be changed to @value.
The action must be stateful and @value must be of the correct type. See [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state_type].
This call merely requests a change. The action may refuse to change its state or may change its state to something other than @value. See [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state_hint].
If the @value GVariant is floating, it is consumed.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to request the change on

function.name: g_action_group_get_action_enabled
function.description:
Checks if the named action within @action_group is currently enabled.
An action must be enabled in order to be activated or in order to have its state changed from outside callers.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to query

function.return: whether the action is currently enabled

function.name: g_action_group_get_action_parameter_type
function.description:
Queries the type of the parameter that must be given when activating the named action within @action_group.
When activating the action using [method@Gio.ActionGroup.activate_action], the [type@GLib.Variant] given to that function must be of the type returned by this function.
In the case that this function returns `NULL`, you must not give any [type@GLib.Variant], but `NULL` instead.
The parameter type of a particular action will never change but it is possible for an action to be removed and for a new action to be added with the same name but a different parameter type.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to query

function.return: the parameter type

function.name: g_action_group_get_action_state
function.description:
Queries the current state of the named action within @action_group.
If the action is not stateful then `NULL` will be returned. If the action is stateful then the type of the return value is the type given by [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state_type].
The return value (if non-`NULL`) should be freed with [method@GLib.Variant.unref] when it is no longer required.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to query

function.return: the current state of the action

function.name: g_action_group_get_action_state_hint
function.description:
Requests a hint about the valid range of values for the state of the named action within @action_group.
If `NULL` is returned it either means that the action is not stateful or that there is no hint about the valid range of values for the state of the action.
If a [type@GLib.Variant] array is returned then each item in the array is a possible value for the state. If a [type@GLib.Variant] pair (ie: two-tuple) is returned then the tuple specifies the inclusive lower and upper bound of valid values for the state.
In any case, the information is merely a hint. It may be possible to have a state value outside of the hinted range and setting a value within the range may fail.
The return value (if non-`NULL`) should be freed with [method@GLib.Variant.unref] when it is no longer required.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to query

function.return: the state range hint

function.name: g_action_group_get_action_state_type
function.description:
Queries the type of the state of the named action within @action_group.
If the action is stateful then this function returns the [type@GLib.VariantType] of the state. All calls to [method@Gio.ActionGroup.change_action_state] must give a [type@GLib.Variant] of this type and [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state] will return a [type@GLib.Variant] of the same type.
If the action is not stateful then this function will return `NULL`. In that case, [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state] will return `NULL` and you must not call [method@Gio.ActionGroup.change_action_state].
The state type of a particular action will never change but it is possible for an action to be removed and for a new action to be added with the same name but a different state type.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to query

function.return: the state type, if the action is stateful

function.name: g_action_group_has_action
function.description:
Checks if the named action exists within @action_group.
Since: 2.28

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action to check for

function.return: whether the named action exists

function.name: g_action_group_list_actions
function.description:
Lists the actions contained within @action_group.
The caller is responsible for freeing the list with [func@GLib.strfreev] when it is no longer required.
Since: 2.28
function.return: a `NULL`-terminated array of the names of the actions in the group

function.name: g_action_group_query_action
function.description:
Queries all aspects of the named action within an @action_group.
This function acquires the information available from [method@Gio.ActionGroup.has_action], [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_enabled], [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_parameter_type], [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state_type], [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state_hint] and [method@Gio.ActionGroup.get_action_state] with a single function call.
This provides two main benefits.
The first is the improvement in efficiency that comes with not having to perform repeated lookups of the action in order to discover different things about it. The second is that implementing [type@Gio.ActionGroup] can now be done by only overriding this one virtual function.
The interface provides a default implementation of this function that calls the individual functions, as required, to fetch the information. The interface also provides default implementations of those functions that call this function. All implementations, therefore, must override either this function or all of the others.
If the action exists, `TRUE` is returned and any of the requested fields (as indicated by having a non-`NULL` reference passed in) are filled. If the action doesn’t exist, `FALSE` is returned and the fields may or may not have been modified.
Since: 2.32

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of an action in the group

parameter.name: enabled
parameter.parameter_description: if the action is presently enabled

parameter.name: parameter_type
parameter.parameter_description: the parameter type, or `NULL` if none needed

parameter.name: state_type
parameter.parameter_description: the state type, or `NULL` if stateless

parameter.name: state_hint
parameter.parameter_description: the state hint, or `NULL` if none

parameter.name: state
parameter.parameter_description: the current state, or `NULL` if stateless

function.return: `TRUE` if the action exists, else `FALSE`

function.name: g_action_map_add_action
function.description:
Adds an action to the @action_map.
If the action map already contains an action with the same name as @action then the old action is dropped from the action map.
The action map takes its own reference on @action.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_action_map_add_action_entries

parameter.name: entries
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the first item in an array of [struct@Gio.ActionEntry] structs

parameter.name: n_entries
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @entries, or -1 if @entries is `NULL`-terminated

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the user data for signal connections

function.name: g_action_map_lookup_action
function.description:
Looks up the action with the name @action_name in @action_map.
If no such action exists, returns `NULL`.
Since: 2.32
function.return: a [iface@Gio.Action]

function.name: g_action_map_remove_action
function.description:
Removes the named action from the action map.
If no action of this name is in the map then nothing happens.
Since: 2.32

function.name: g_action_map_remove_action_entries

parameter.name: entries
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to the first item in an array of [struct@Gio.ActionEntry] structs

parameter.name: n_entries
parameter.parameter_description: the length of @entries, or -1 if @entries is `NULL`-terminated

function.name: g_action_name_is_valid
function.return: `TRUE` if @action_name is valid

function.name: g_action_parse_detailed_name
function.description:
Parses a detailed action name into its separate name and target components.
Detailed action names can have three formats.
The first format is used to represent an action name with no target value and consists of just an action name containing no whitespace nor the characters `:`, `(` or `)`. For example: `app.action`.
The second format is used to represent an action with a target value that is a non-empty string consisting only of alphanumerics, plus `-` and `.`. In that case, the action name and target value are separated by a double colon (`::`). For example: `app.action::target`.
The third format is used to represent an action with any type of target value, including strings. The target value follows the action name, surrounded in parens. For example: `app.action(42)`. The target value is parsed using [func@GLib.Variant.parse]. If a tuple-typed value is desired, it must be specified in the same way, resulting in two sets of parens, for example: `app.action((1,2,3))`. A string target can be specified this way as well: `app.action('target')`. For strings, this third format must be used if target value is empty or contains characters other than alphanumerics, `-` and `.`.
If this function returns `TRUE`, a non-`NULL` value is guaranteed to be returned in @action_name (if a pointer is passed in). A `NULL` value may still be returned in @target_value, as the @detailed_name may not contain a target.
If returned, the [type@GLib.Variant] in @target_value is guaranteed to not be floating.
Since: 2.38

parameter.name: target_value
parameter.parameter_description: the target value, or `NULL` for no target

function.return: `TRUE` if successful, else `FALSE` with @error set

function.name: g_action_print_detailed_name
function.description:
Formats a detailed action name from @action_name and @target_value.
It is an error to call this function with an invalid action name.
This function is the opposite of [func@Gio.Action.parse_detailed_name]. It will produce a string that can be parsed back to the @action_name and @target_value by that function.
See that function for the types of strings that will be printed by this function.
Since: 2.38
function.return: a detailed format string

function.name: g_app_info_add_supports_type
function.description: Adds a content type to the application information to indicate the application is capable of opening files with the given content type.
function.return: `TRUE` on success, `FALSE` on error.

function.name: g_app_info_can_delete
function.description:
Obtains the information whether the [iface@Gio.AppInfo] can be deleted. See [method@Gio.AppInfo.delete].
Since: 2.20
function.return: `TRUE` if @appinfo can be deleted

function.name: g_app_info_can_remove_supports_type
function.description: Checks if a supported content type can be removed from an application.
function.return: `TRUE` if it is possible to remove supported content types from a given @appinfo, `FALSE` if not.

function.name: g_app_info_create_from_commandline
function.description:
Creates a new [iface@Gio.AppInfo] from the given information.
Note that for @commandline, the quoting rules of the `Exec` key of the [freedesktop.org Desktop Entry Specification](http://freedesktop.org/Standards/desktop-entry-spec) are applied. For example, if the @commandline contains percent-encoded URIs, the percent-character must be doubled in order to prevent it from being swallowed by `Exec` key unquoting. See [the specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s07.html) for exact quoting rules.

parameter.name: application_name
parameter.parameter_description: the application name, or `NULL` to use @commandline

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags that can specify details of the created [iface@Gio.AppInfo]

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a [type@GLib.Error] location to store the error occurring, `NULL` to ignore.

function.return: new [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for given command.

function.name: g_app_info_delete
function.description:
Tries to delete a [iface@Gio.AppInfo].
On some platforms, there may be a difference between user-defined [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s which can be deleted, and system-wide ones which cannot. See [method@Gio.AppInfo.can_delete].
Since: 2.20
function.return: `TRUE` if @appinfo has been deleted

function.name: g_app_info_dup
function.description: Creates a duplicate of a [iface@Gio.AppInfo].
function.return: a duplicate of @appinfo.

function.name: g_app_info_equal
function.description:
Checks if two [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s are equal.
Note that the check *may not* compare each individual field, and only does an identity check. In case detecting changes in the contents is needed, program code must additionally compare relevant fields.
function.return: `TRUE` if @appinfo1 is equal to @appinfo2. `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: g_app_info_get_all
function.description:
Gets a list of all of the applications currently registered on this system.
For desktop files, this includes applications that have [`NoDisplay=true`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-nodisplay) set or are excluded from display by means of [`OnlyShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-onlyshowin) or [`NotShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-notshowin). See [method@Gio.AppInfo.should_show].
The returned list does not include applications which have the [`Hidden` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-hidden) set.
function.return: a newly allocated list of references to [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s.

function.name: g_app_info_get_all_for_type
function.description: Gets a list of all [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s for a given content type, including the recommended and fallback [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s. See [func@Gio.AppInfo.get_recommended_for_type] and [func@Gio.AppInfo.get_fallback_for_type].

parameter.name: content_type
parameter.parameter_description: the content type to find a [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for

function.return: list of [iface@Gio.AppInfo]s for given @content_type.

function.name: g_app_info_get_commandline
function.description:
Gets the commandline with which the application will be started.
Since: 2.20
function.return: a string containing the @appinfo’s commandline, or `NULL` if this information is not available

function.name: g_app_info_get_default_for_type
function.description: Gets the default [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for a given content type.

parameter.name: content_type
parameter.parameter_description: the content type to find a [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for

parameter.name: must_support_uris
parameter.parameter_description: if `TRUE`, the [iface@Gio.AppInfo] is expected to support URIs

function.return: [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for given @content_type or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_app_info_get_default_for_type_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the default [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for a given content type.
Since: 2.74

parameter.name: content_type
parameter.parameter_description: the content type to find a [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for

parameter.name: must_support_uris
parameter.parameter_description: if `TRUE`, the [iface@Gio.AppInfo] is expected to support URIs

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a [type@Gio.AsyncReadyCallback] to call when the request is done

function.name: g_app_info_get_default_for_type_finish
function.description:
Finishes a default [iface@Gio.AppInfo] lookup started by [func@Gio.AppInfo.get_default_for_type_async].
If no #[iface@Gio.AppInfo] is found, then @error will be set to [error@Gio.IOErrorEnum.NOT_FOUND].
Since: 2.74
function.return: [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for given @content_type or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_app_info_get_default_for_uri_scheme
function.description:
Gets the default application for handling URIs with the given URI scheme.
A URI scheme is the initial part of the URI, up to but not including the `:`. For example, `http`, `ftp` or `sip`.

parameter.name: uri_scheme
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a URI scheme.

function.return: [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for given @uri_scheme or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_app_info_get_default_for_uri_scheme_async
function.description:
Asynchronously gets the default application for handling URIs with the given URI scheme. A URI scheme is the initial part of the URI, up to but not including the `:`, e.g. `http`, `ftp` or `sip`.
Since: 2.74

parameter.name: uri_scheme
