parameter.parameter_description: A #GAsyncResult obtained from the #GAsyncReadyCallback passed to g_dbus_proxy_call().

function.return: %NULL if @error is set. Otherwise a #GVariant tuple with return values. Free with g_variant_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_call_sync
function.description:
Synchronously invokes the @method_name method on @proxy.
If @method_name contains any dots, then @name is split into interface and method name parts. This allows using @proxy for invoking methods on other interfaces.
If the #GDBusConnection associated with @proxy is disconnected then the operation will fail with %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED. If @cancellable is canceled, the operation will fail with %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED. If @parameters contains a value not compatible with the D-Bus protocol, the operation fails with %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_ARGUMENT.
If the @parameters #GVariant is floating, it is consumed. This allows convenient 'inline' use of g_variant_new(), e.g.: |[<!-- language="C" --> g_dbus_proxy_call_sync (proxy, "TwoStrings", g_variant_new ("(ss)", "Thing One", "Thing Two"), G_DBUS_CALL_FLAGS_NONE, -1, NULL, &error); ]|
The calling thread is blocked until a reply is received. See g_dbus_proxy_call() for the asynchronous version of this method.
If @proxy has an expected interface (see #GDBusProxy:g-interface-info) and @method_name is referenced by it, then the return value is checked against the return type.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: parameters
parameter.parameter_description: A #GVariant tuple with parameters for the signal or %NULL if not passing parameters.

parameter.name: timeout_msec
parameter.parameter_description: The timeout in milliseconds (with %G_MAXINT meaning "infinite") or -1 to use the proxy default timeout.

function.return: %NULL if @error is set. Otherwise a #GVariant tuple with return values. Free with g_variant_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_call_with_unix_fd_list
function.description:
Like g_dbus_proxy_call() but also takes a #GUnixFDList object.
This method is only available on UNIX.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: parameters
parameter.parameter_description: A #GVariant tuple with parameters for the signal or %NULL if not passing parameters.

parameter.name: timeout_msec
parameter.parameter_description: The timeout in milliseconds (with %G_MAXINT meaning "infinite") or -1 to use the proxy default timeout.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: A #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied or %NULL if you don't care about the result of the method invocation.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_call_with_unix_fd_list_finish
function.description:
Finishes an operation started with g_dbus_proxy_call_with_unix_fd_list().
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: A #GAsyncResult obtained from the #GAsyncReadyCallback passed to g_dbus_proxy_call_with_unix_fd_list().

function.return: %NULL if @error is set. Otherwise a #GVariant tuple with return values. Free with g_variant_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_call_with_unix_fd_list_sync
function.description:
Like g_dbus_proxy_call_sync() but also takes and returns #GUnixFDList objects.
This method is only available on UNIX.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: parameters
parameter.parameter_description: A #GVariant tuple with parameters for the signal or %NULL if not passing parameters.

parameter.name: timeout_msec
parameter.parameter_description: The timeout in milliseconds (with %G_MAXINT meaning "infinite") or -1 to use the proxy default timeout.

function.return: %NULL if @error is set. Otherwise a #GVariant tuple with return values. Free with g_variant_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_cached_property
function.description:
Looks up the value for a property from the cache. This call does no blocking IO.
If @proxy has an expected interface (see #GDBusProxy:g-interface-info) and @property_name is referenced by it, then @value is checked against the type of the property.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A reference to the #GVariant instance that holds the value for @property_name or %NULL if the value is not in the cache. The returned reference must be freed with g_variant_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_cached_property_names
function.description:
Gets the names of all cached properties on @proxy.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A %NULL-terminated array of strings or %NULL if @proxy has no cached properties. Free the returned array with g_strfreev().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_connection
function.description:
Gets the connection @proxy is for.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A #GDBusConnection owned by @proxy. Do not free.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_default_timeout
function.description:
Gets the timeout to use if -1 (specifying default timeout) is passed as @timeout_msec in the g_dbus_proxy_call() and g_dbus_proxy_call_sync() functions.
See the #GDBusProxy:g-default-timeout property for more details.
Since: 2.26
function.return: Timeout to use for @proxy.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_flags
function.description:
Gets the flags that @proxy was constructed with.
Since: 2.26
function.return: Flags from the #GDBusProxyFlags enumeration.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_interface_info
function.description:
Returns the #GDBusInterfaceInfo, if any, specifying the interface that @proxy conforms to. See the #GDBusProxy:g-interface-info property for more details.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A #GDBusInterfaceInfo or %NULL. Do not unref the returned object, it is owned by @proxy.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_interface_name
function.description:
Gets the D-Bus interface name @proxy is for.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A string owned by @proxy. Do not free.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_name
function.description:
Gets the name that @proxy was constructed for.
When connected to a message bus, this will usually be non-%NULL. However, it may be %NULL for a proxy that communicates using a peer-to-peer pattern.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A string owned by @proxy. Do not free.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_name_owner
function.description:
The unique name that owns the name that @proxy is for or %NULL if no-one currently owns that name. You may connect to the #GObject::notify signal to track changes to the #GDBusProxy:g-name-owner property.
Since: 2.26
function.return: The name owner or %NULL if no name owner exists. Free with g_free().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_get_object_path
function.description:
Gets the object path @proxy is for.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A string owned by @proxy. Do not free.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new
function.description:
Creates a proxy for accessing @interface_name on the remote object at @object_path owned by @name at @connection and asynchronously loads D-Bus properties unless the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_LOAD_PROPERTIES flag is used. Connect to the #GDBusProxy::g-properties-changed signal to get notified about property changes.
If the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_CONNECT_SIGNALS flag is not set, also sets up match rules for signals. Connect to the #GDBusProxy::g-signal signal to handle signals from the remote object.
If both %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_LOAD_PROPERTIES and %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_CONNECT_SIGNALS are set, this constructor is guaranteed to complete immediately without blocking.
If @name is a well-known name and the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_AUTO_START and %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_AUTO_START_AT_CONSTRUCTION flags aren't set and no name owner currently exists, the message bus will be requested to launch a name owner for the name.
This is a failable asynchronous constructor - when the proxy is ready, @callback will be invoked and you can use g_dbus_proxy_new_finish() to get the result.
See g_dbus_proxy_new_sync() and for a synchronous version of this constructor.
#GDBusProxy is used in this [example][class@Gio.DBusProxy#a-watch-proxy-example].
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: Flags used when constructing the proxy.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: A #GDBusInterfaceInfo specifying the minimal interface that @proxy conforms to or %NULL.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: A bus name (well-known or unique) or %NULL if @connection is not a message bus connection.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: Callback function to invoke when the proxy is ready.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new_finish
function.description:
Finishes creating a #GDBusProxy.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: A #GAsyncResult obtained from the #GAsyncReadyCallback function passed to g_dbus_proxy_new().

function.return: A #GDBusProxy or %NULL if @error is set. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new_for_bus
function.description:
Like g_dbus_proxy_new() but takes a #GBusType instead of a #GDBusConnection.
#GDBusProxy is used in this [example][class@Gio.DBusProxy#a-watch-proxy-example].
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: Flags used when constructing the proxy.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: A #GDBusInterfaceInfo specifying the minimal interface that @proxy conforms to or %NULL.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: Callback function to invoke when the proxy is ready.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new_for_bus_finish
function.description:
Finishes creating a #GDBusProxy.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: res
parameter.parameter_description: A #GAsyncResult obtained from the #GAsyncReadyCallback function passed to g_dbus_proxy_new_for_bus().

function.return: A #GDBusProxy or %NULL if @error is set. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new_for_bus_sync
function.description:
Like g_dbus_proxy_new_sync() but takes a #GBusType instead of a #GDBusConnection.
#GDBusProxy is used in this [example][class@Gio.DBusProxy#a-watch-proxy-example].
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: Flags used when constructing the proxy.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: A #GDBusInterfaceInfo specifying the minimal interface that @proxy conforms to or %NULL.

function.return: A #GDBusProxy or %NULL if error is set. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_new_sync
function.description:
Creates a proxy for accessing @interface_name on the remote object at @object_path owned by @name at @connection and synchronously loads D-Bus properties unless the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_LOAD_PROPERTIES flag is used.
If the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_CONNECT_SIGNALS flag is not set, also sets up match rules for signals. Connect to the #GDBusProxy::g-signal signal to handle signals from the remote object.
If both %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_LOAD_PROPERTIES and %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_CONNECT_SIGNALS are set, this constructor is guaranteed to return immediately without blocking.
If @name is a well-known name and the %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_AUTO_START and %G_DBUS_PROXY_FLAGS_DO_NOT_AUTO_START_AT_CONSTRUCTION flags aren't set and no name owner currently exists, the message bus will be requested to launch a name owner for the name.
This is a synchronous failable constructor. See g_dbus_proxy_new() and g_dbus_proxy_new_finish() for the asynchronous version.
#GDBusProxy is used in this [example][class@Gio.DBusProxy#a-watch-proxy-example].
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: Flags used when constructing the proxy.

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: A #GDBusInterfaceInfo specifying the minimal interface that @proxy conforms to or %NULL.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: A bus name (well-known or unique) or %NULL if @connection is not a message bus connection.

function.return: A #GDBusProxy or %NULL if error is set. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_set_cached_property
function.description:
If @value is not %NULL, sets the cached value for the property with name @property_name to the value in @value.
If @value is %NULL, then the cached value is removed from the property cache.
If @proxy has an expected interface (see #GDBusProxy:g-interface-info) and @property_name is referenced by it, then @value is checked against the type of the property.
If the @value #GVariant is floating, it is consumed. This allows convenient 'inline' use of g_variant_new(), e.g. |[<!-- language="C" --> g_dbus_proxy_set_cached_property (proxy, "SomeProperty", g_variant_new ("(si)", "A String", 42)); ]|
Normally you will not need to use this method since @proxy is tracking changes using the `org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties.PropertiesChanged` D-Bus signal. However, for performance reasons an object may decide to not use this signal for some properties and instead use a proprietary out-of-band mechanism to transmit changes.
As a concrete example, consider an object with a property `ChatroomParticipants` which is an array of strings. Instead of transmitting the same (long) array every time the property changes, it is more efficient to only transmit the delta using e.g. signals `ChatroomParticipantJoined(String name)` and `ChatroomParticipantParted(String name)`.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: value
parameter.parameter_description: Value for the property or %NULL to remove it from the cache.

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_set_default_timeout
function.description:
Sets the timeout to use if -1 (specifying default timeout) is passed as @timeout_msec in the g_dbus_proxy_call() and g_dbus_proxy_call_sync() functions.
See the #GDBusProxy:g-default-timeout property for more details.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_dbus_proxy_set_interface_info
function.description:
Ensure that interactions with @proxy conform to the given interface. See the #GDBusProxy:g-interface-info property for more details.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: info
parameter.parameter_description: Minimum interface this proxy conforms to or %NULL to unset.

function.name: g_dbus_server_get_client_address
function.description:
Gets a [D-Bus address](https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#addresses) string that can be used by clients to connect to @server.
This is valid and non-empty if initializing the #GDBusServer succeeded.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A D-Bus address string. Do not free, the string is owned by @server.

function.name: g_dbus_server_get_flags
function.description:
Gets the flags for @server.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A set of flags from the #GDBusServerFlags enumeration.

function.name: g_dbus_server_get_guid
function.description:
Gets the GUID for @server, as provided to g_dbus_server_new_sync().
Since: 2.26
function.return: A D-Bus GUID. Do not free this string, it is owned by @server.

function.name: g_dbus_server_is_active
function.description:
Gets whether @server is active.
Since: 2.26
function.return: %TRUE if server is active, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_dbus_server_new_sync
function.description:
Creates a new D-Bus server that listens on the first address in @address that works.
Once constructed, you can use g_dbus_server_get_client_address() to get a D-Bus address string that clients can use to connect.
To have control over the available authentication mechanisms and the users that are authorized to connect, it is strongly recommended to provide a non-%NULL #GDBusAuthObserver.
Connect to the #GDBusServer::new-connection signal to handle incoming connections.
The returned #GDBusServer isn't active - you have to start it with g_dbus_server_start().
#GDBusServer is used in this [example](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/-/blob/HEAD/gio/tests/gdbus-example-peer.c).
This is a synchronous failable constructor. There is currently no asynchronous version.
Since: 2.26
function.return: A #GDBusServer or %NULL if @error is set. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_dbus_server_start
function.description:
Starts @server.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_dbus_server_stop
function.description:
Stops @server.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_dbus_signal_info_ref
function.description:
If @info is statically allocated does nothing. Otherwise increases the reference count.
Since: 2.26
function.return: The same @info.

function.name: g_dbus_signal_info_unref
function.description:
If @info is statically allocated, does nothing. Otherwise decreases the reference count of @info. When its reference count drops to 0, the memory used is freed.
Since: 2.26

function.name: g_dbus_unescape_object_path
function.description:
Unescapes an string that was previously escaped with g_dbus_escape_object_path(). If the string is in a format that could not have been returned by g_dbus_escape_object_path(), this function returns %NULL.
Encoding alphanumeric characters which do not need to be encoded is not allowed (e.g `_63` is not valid, the string should contain `c` instead).
Since: 2.68
function.return: an unescaped version of @s, or %NULL if @s is not a string returned from g_dbus_escape_object_path(). Free with g_free().

function.name: g_debug_controller_dbus_new
function.description:
Create a new #GDebugControllerDBus and synchronously initialize it.
Initializing the object will export the debug object on @connection. The object will remain registered until the last reference to the #GDebugControllerDBus is dropped.
Initialization may fail if registering the object on @connection fails.
Since: 2.72

parameter.name: connection
parameter.parameter_description: a #GDBusConnection to register the debug object on

function.return: a new #GDebugControllerDBus, or %NULL on failure

function.name: g_debug_controller_dbus_stop
function.description:
Stop the debug controller, unregistering its object from the bus.
Any pending method calls to the object will complete successfully, but new ones will return an error. This method will block until all pending #GDebugControllerDBus::authorize signals have been handled. This is expected to not take long, as it will just be waiting for threads to join. If any #GDebugControllerDBus::authorize signal handlers are still executing in other threads, this will block until after they have returned.
This method will be called automatically when the final reference to the #GDebugControllerDBus is dropped. You may want to call it explicitly to know when the controller has been fully removed from the bus, or to break reference count cycles.
Calling this method from within a #GDebugControllerDBus::authorize signal handler will cause a deadlock and must not be done.
Since: 2.72

function.name: g_debug_controller_get_debug_enabled
function.description:
Get the value of #GDebugController:debug-enabled.
Since: 2.72
function.return: %TRUE if debug output should be exposed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_debug_controller_set_debug_enabled
function.description:
Set the value of #GDebugController:debug-enabled.
Since: 2.72

parameter.name: debug_enabled
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if debug output should be exposed, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_action_name
function.description:
Gets the user-visible display name of the [‘additional application actions’](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s11.html) specified by @action_name.
This corresponds to the `Name` key within the keyfile group for the action.
Since: 2.38

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action as from [method@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.list_actions]

function.return: the locale-specific action name

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_boolean
function.description:
Looks up a boolean value in the keyfile backing @info.
The @key is looked up in the `Desktop Entry` group.
Since: 2.36
function.return: the boolean value, or `FALSE` if the key is not found

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_categories
function.description: Gets the categories from the desktop file.
function.return: The unparsed [`Categories` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-categories) from the desktop file; i.e. no attempt is made to split it by `;` or validate it.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_filename
function.description:
When @info was created from a known filename, return it.
In some situations such as a [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] returned from [ctor@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.new_from_keyfile], this function will return `NULL`.
Since: 2.24
function.return: The full path to the file for @info, or `NULL` if not known.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_generic_name
function.description: Gets the generic name from the desktop file.
function.return: The value of the [`GenericName` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-genericname)

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_implementations
function.description:
Gets all applications that implement @interface.
An application implements an interface if that interface is listed in the `Implements` line of the desktop file of the application.
Since: 2.42
function.return: a list of [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] objects.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_is_hidden
function.description: A desktop file is hidden if the [`Hidden` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-hidden) in it is set to `True`.
function.return: `TRUE` if hidden, `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_keywords
function.description:
Gets the keywords from the desktop file.
Since: 2.32
function.return: The value of the [`Keywords` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-keywords)

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_locale_string
function.description:
Looks up a localized string value in the keyfile backing @info translated to the current locale.
The @key is looked up in the `Desktop Entry` group.
Since: 2.56
function.return: a newly allocated string, or `NULL` if the key is not found

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_nodisplay
function.description:
Gets the value of the [`NoDisplay` key](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-nodisplay) which helps determine if the application info should be shown in menus. See `G_KEY_FILE_DESKTOP_KEY_NO_DISPLAY` and [method@Gio.AppInfo.should_show].
Since: 2.30
function.return: The value of the `NoDisplay` key

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_show_in
function.description:
Checks if the application info should be shown in menus that list available applications for a specific name of the desktop, based on the [`OnlyShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-onlyshowin) and [`NotShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-notshowin) keys.
@desktop_env should typically be given as `NULL`, in which case the `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP` environment variable is consulted. If you want to override the default mechanism then you may specify @desktop_env, but this is not recommended.
Note that [method@Gio.AppInfo.should_show] for @info will include this check (with `NULL` for @desktop_env) as well as additional checks.
Since: 2.30

parameter.name: desktop_env
parameter.parameter_description: a string specifying a desktop name

function.return: `TRUE` if the @info should be shown in @desktop_env according to the `OnlyShowIn` and `NotShowIn` keys, `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_startup_wm_class
function.description:
Retrieves the `StartupWMClass` field from @info. This represents the `WM_CLASS` property of the main window of the application, if launched through @info.
Since: 2.34
function.return: the startup WM class, or `NULL` if none is set in the desktop file.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_string
function.description:
Looks up a string value in the keyfile backing @info.
The @key is looked up in the `Desktop Entry` group.
Since: 2.36
function.return: a newly allocated string, or `NULL` if the key is not found

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_get_string_list
function.description:
Looks up a string list value in the keyfile backing @info.
The @key is looked up in the `Desktop Entry` group.
Since: 2.60

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of returned strings, or `NULL`

function.return: a `NULL`-terminated string array or `NULL` if the specified key cannot be found. The array should be freed with [func@GLib.strfreev].

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_has_key
function.description:
Returns whether @key exists in the `Desktop Entry` group of the keyfile backing @info.
Since: 2.36
function.return: `TRUE` if the @key exists

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_launch_action
function.description:
Activates the named application action.
You may only call this function on action names that were returned from [method@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.list_actions].
Note that if the main entry of the desktop file indicates that the application supports startup notification, and @launch_context is non-`NULL`, then startup notification will be used when activating the action (and as such, invocation of the action on the receiving side must signal the end of startup notification when it is completed). This is the expected behaviour of applications declaring additional actions, as per the [desktop file specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s11.html).
As with [method@Gio.AppInfo.launch] there is no way to detect failures that occur while using this function.
Since: 2.38

parameter.name: action_name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the action as from [method@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.list_actions]

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_launch_uris_as_manager
function.description:
This function performs the equivalent of [method@Gio.AppInfo.launch_uris], but is intended primarily for operating system components that launch applications. Ordinary applications should use [method@Gio.AppInfo.launch_uris].
If the application is launched via GSpawn, then @spawn_flags, @user_setup and @user_setup_data are used for the call to [func@GLib.spawn_async]. Additionally, @pid_callback (with @pid_callback_data) will be called to inform about the PID of the created process. See [func@GLib.spawn_async_with_pipes] for information on certain parameter conditions that can enable an optimized [`posix_spawn()`](man:posix_spawn(3)) code path to be used.
If application launching occurs via some other mechanism (for example, D-Bus activation) then @spawn_flags, @user_setup, @user_setup_data, @pid_callback and @pid_callback_data are ignored.

parameter.name: user_setup
parameter.parameter_description: a [callback@GLib.SpawnChildSetupFunc], used once for each process.

function.return: `TRUE` on successful launch, `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_launch_uris_as_manager_with_fds
function.description:
Equivalent to [method@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.launch_uris_as_manager] but allows you to pass in file descriptors for the stdin, stdout and stderr streams of the launched process.
If application launching occurs via some non-spawn mechanism (e.g. D-Bus activation) then @stdin_fd, @stdout_fd and @stderr_fd are ignored.
Since: 2.58

parameter.name: user_setup
parameter.parameter_description: a [callback@GLib.SpawnChildSetupFunc], used once for each process.

parameter.name: stdin_fd
parameter.parameter_description: file descriptor to use for child’s stdin, or `-1`

parameter.name: stdout_fd
parameter.parameter_description: file descriptor to use for child’s stdout, or `-1`

parameter.name: stderr_fd
parameter.parameter_description: file descriptor to use for child’s stderr, or `-1`

function.return: `TRUE` on successful launch, `FALSE` otherwise.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_list_actions
function.description:
Returns the list of [‘additional application actions’](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s11.html) supported on the desktop file, as per the desktop file specification.
As per the specification, this is the list of actions that are explicitly listed in the `Actions` key of the `Desktop Entry` group.
Since: 2.38
function.return: a list of strings, always non-`NULL`

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_lookup_get_default_for_uri_scheme
function.description:
Gets the default application for launching applications using this URI scheme for a particular [iface@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfoLookup] implementation.
The [iface@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfoLookup] interface and this function is used to implement [func@Gio.AppInfo.get_default_for_uri_scheme] backends in a GIO module. There is no reason for applications to use it directly. Applications should use [func@Gio.AppInfo.get_default_for_uri_scheme].
Deprecated: 2.28: The [iface@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfoLookup] interface is deprecated and unused by GIO.

parameter.name: uri_scheme
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a URI scheme.

function.return: [iface@Gio.AppInfo] for given @uri_scheme or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_new
function.description:
Creates a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] based on a desktop file ID.
A desktop file ID is the basename of the desktop file, including the `.desktop` extension. GIO is looking for a desktop file with this name in the `applications` subdirectories of the XDG data directories (i.e. the directories specified in the `XDG_DATA_HOME` and `XDG_DATA_DIRS` environment variables). GIO also supports the prefix-to-subdirectory mapping that is described in the [Menu Spec](http://standards.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/) (i.e. a desktop ID of `kde-foo.desktop` will match `/usr/share/applications/kde/foo.desktop`).
function.return: a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo], or `NULL` if no desktop file with that ID exists.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_new_from_filename
function.description: Creates a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo].

parameter.name: filename
parameter.parameter_description: the path of a desktop file, in the GLib filename encoding

function.return: a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_new_from_keyfile
function.description:
Creates a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo].
Since: 2.18
function.return: a new [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] or `NULL` on error.

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_search
function.description:
Searches desktop files for ones that match @search_string.
The return value is an array of strvs. Each strv contains a list of applications that matched @search_string with an equal score. The outer list is sorted by score so that the first strv contains the best-matching applications, and so on. The algorithm for determining matches is undefined and may change at any time.
None of the search results are subjected to the normal validation checks performed by [ctor@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.new] (for example, checking that the executable referenced by a result exists), and so it is possible for [ctor@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.new] to return `NULL` when passed an app ID returned by this function. It is expected that calling code will do this when subsequently creating a [class@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo] for each result.
function.return: a list of strvs. Free each item with [func@GLib.strfreev] and free the outer list with [func@GLib.free].

function.name: g_desktop_app_info_set_desktop_env
function.description:
Sets the name of the desktop that the application is running in.
This is used by [method@Gio.AppInfo.should_show] and [method@GioUnix.DesktopAppInfo.get_show_in] to evaluate the [`OnlyShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-onlyshowin) and [`NotShowIn`](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/latest/ar01s06.html#key-notshowin) keys.
Should be called only once; subsequent calls are ignored.
Deprecated:2.42:do not use this API. Since 2.42 the value of the `XDG_CURRENT_DESKTOP` environment variable will be used.

parameter.name: desktop_env
parameter.parameter_description: a string specifying what desktop this is

function.name: g_drive_can_eject
function.description: Checks if a drive can be ejected.
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive can be ejected, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_can_poll_for_media
function.description: Checks if a drive can be polled for media changes.
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive can be polled for media changes, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_can_start
function.description:
Checks if a drive can be started.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive can be started, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_can_start_degraded
function.description:
Checks if a drive can be started degraded.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive can be started degraded, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_can_stop
function.description:
Checks if a drive can be stopped.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive can be stopped, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_eject
function.description:
Asynchronously ejects a drive.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_drive_eject_finish() to obtain the result of the operation.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_drive_eject_with_operation() instead.

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting the unmount if required for eject

function.name: g_drive_eject_finish
function.description:
Finishes ejecting a drive.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_drive_eject_with_operation_finish() instead.
function.return: %TRUE if the drive has been ejected successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_eject_with_operation
function.description:
Ejects a drive. This is an asynchronous operation, and is finished by calling g_drive_eject_with_operation_finish() with the @drive and #GAsyncResult data returned in the @callback.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting the unmount if required for eject

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction.

function.name: g_drive_eject_with_operation_finish

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store the error occurring, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: %TRUE if the drive was successfully ejected. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_enumerate_identifiers
function.description: Gets the kinds of identifiers that @drive has. Use g_drive_get_identifier() to obtain the identifiers themselves.
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings containing kinds of identifiers. Use g_strfreev() to free.

function.name: g_drive_get_icon
function.description: Gets the icon for @drive.
function.return: #GIcon for the @drive. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_drive_get_identifier
function.description: Gets the identifier of the given kind for @drive. The only identifier currently available is %G_DRIVE_IDENTIFIER_KIND_UNIX_DEVICE.

parameter.name: kind
parameter.parameter_description: the kind of identifier to return

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the requested identifier, or %NULL if the #GDrive doesn't have this kind of identifier.

function.name: g_drive_get_name
function.description: Gets the name of @drive.
function.return: a string containing @drive's name. The returned string should be freed when no longer needed.

function.name: g_drive_get_sort_key
function.description:
Gets the sort key for @drive, if any.
Since: 2.32
function.return: Sorting key for @drive or %NULL if no such key is available.

function.name: g_drive_get_start_stop_type
function.description:
Gets a hint about how a drive can be started/stopped.
Since: 2.22
function.return: A value from the #GDriveStartStopType enumeration.

function.name: g_drive_get_symbolic_icon
function.description:
Gets the icon for @drive.
Since: 2.34
function.return: symbolic #GIcon for the @drive. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_drive_get_volumes
function.description:
Get a list of mountable volumes for @drive.
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().
function.return: #GList containing any #GVolume objects on the given @drive.

function.name: g_drive_has_media
function.description: Checks if the @drive has media. Note that the OS may not be polling the drive for media changes; see g_drive_is_media_check_automatic() for more details.
function.return: %TRUE if @drive has media, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_has_volumes
function.description: Check if @drive has any mountable volumes.
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive contains volumes, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_is_media_check_automatic
function.description: Checks if @drive is capable of automatically detecting media changes.
function.return: %TRUE if the @drive is capable of automatically detecting media changes, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_is_media_removable
function.description: Checks if the @drive supports removable media.
function.return: %TRUE if @drive supports removable media, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_is_removable
function.description:
Checks if the #GDrive and/or its media is considered removable by the user. See g_drive_is_media_removable().
Since: 2.50
function.return: %TRUE if @drive and/or its media is considered removable, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_poll_for_media
function.description:
Asynchronously polls @drive to see if media has been inserted or removed.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_drive_poll_for_media_finish() to obtain the result of the operation.

function.name: g_drive_poll_for_media_finish
function.description: Finishes an operation started with g_drive_poll_for_media() on a drive.
function.return: %TRUE if the drive has been poll_for_mediaed successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_start
function.description:
Asynchronously starts a drive.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_drive_start_finish() to obtain the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction.

function.name: g_drive_start_finish
function.description:
Finishes starting a drive.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the drive has been started successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_drive_stop
function.description:
Asynchronously stops a drive.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_drive_stop_finish() to obtain the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting the unmount if required for stopping.

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction.

function.name: g_drive_stop_finish
function.description:
Finishes stopping a drive.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the drive has been stopped successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_get_accepted_cas
function.description:
Gets the list of distinguished names of the Certificate Authorities that the server will accept certificates from. This will be set during the TLS handshake if the server requests a certificate. Otherwise, it will be %NULL.
Each item in the list is a #GByteArray which contains the complete subject DN of the certificate authority.
Since: 2.48
function.return: the list of CA DNs. You should unref each element with g_byte_array_unref() and then the free the list with g_list_free().

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_get_server_identity
function.description:
Gets @conn's expected server identity
Since: 2.48
function.return: a #GSocketConnectable describing the expected server identity, or %NULL if the expected identity is not known.

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_get_validation_flags
function.description:
Gets @conn's validation flags
This function does not work as originally designed and is impossible to use correctly. See #GDtlsClientConnection:validation-flags for more information.
Since: 2.48
Deprecated: 2.74: Do not attempt to ignore validation errors.
function.return: the validation flags

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GDtlsClientConnection wrapping @base_socket which is assumed to communicate with the server identified by @server_identity.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: server_identity
parameter.parameter_description: the expected identity of the server

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError for error reporting, or %NULL to ignore.

function.return: the new #GDtlsClientConnection, or %NULL on error

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_set_server_identity
function.description:
Sets @conn's expected server identity, which is used both to tell servers on virtual hosts which certificate to present, and also to let @conn know what name to look for in the certificate when performing %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_BAD_IDENTITY validation, if enabled.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: identity
parameter.parameter_description: a #GSocketConnectable describing the expected server identity

function.name: g_dtls_client_connection_set_validation_flags
function.description:
Sets @conn's validation flags, to override the default set of checks performed when validating a server certificate. By default, %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_VALIDATE_ALL is used.
This function does not work as originally designed and is impossible to use correctly. See #GDtlsClientConnection:validation-flags for more information.
Since: 2.48
Deprecated: 2.74: Do not attempt to ignore validation errors.

function.name: g_dtls_connection_close
function.description:
Close the DTLS connection. This is equivalent to calling g_dtls_connection_shutdown() to shut down both sides of the connection.
Closing a #GDtlsConnection waits for all buffered but untransmitted data to be sent before it completes. It then sends a `close_notify` DTLS alert to the peer and may wait for a `close_notify` to be received from the peer. It does not close the underlying #GDtlsConnection:base-socket; that must be closed separately.
Once @conn is closed, all other operations will return %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED. Closing a #GDtlsConnection multiple times will not return an error.
#GDtlsConnections will be automatically closed when the last reference is dropped, but you might want to call this function to make sure resources are released as early as possible.
If @cancellable is cancelled, the #GDtlsConnection may be left partially-closed and any pending untransmitted data may be lost. Call g_dtls_connection_close() again to complete closing the #GDtlsConnection.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_dtls_connection_close_async
function.description:
Asynchronously close the DTLS connection. See g_dtls_connection_close() for more information.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the close operation is complete

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: g_dtls_connection_close_finish
function.description:
Finish an asynchronous TLS close operation. See g_dtls_connection_close() for more information.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure, in which case @error will be set

function.name: g_dtls_connection_emit_accept_certificate
function.description:
Used by #GDtlsConnection implementations to emit the #GDtlsConnection::accept-certificate signal.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE if one of the signal handlers has returned %TRUE to accept @peer_cert

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_certificate
function.description:
Gets @conn's certificate, as set by g_dtls_connection_set_certificate().
Since: 2.48
function.return: @conn's certificate, or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_channel_binding_data
function.description:
Query the TLS backend for TLS channel binding data of @type for @conn.
This call retrieves TLS channel binding data as specified in RFC [5056](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5056), RFC [5929](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5929), and related RFCs. The binding data is returned in @data. The @data is resized by the callee using #GByteArray buffer management and will be freed when the @data is destroyed by g_byte_array_unref(). If @data is %NULL, it will only check whether TLS backend is able to fetch the data (e.g. whether @type is supported by the TLS backend). It does not guarantee that the data will be available though. That could happen if TLS connection does not support @type or the binding data is not available yet due to additional negotiation or input required.
Since: 2.66

parameter.name: data
parameter.parameter_description: #GByteArray is filled with the binding data, or %NULL

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_ciphersuite_name
function.description:
Returns the name of the current DTLS ciphersuite, or %NULL if the connection has not handshaked or has been closed. Beware that the TLS backend may use any of multiple different naming conventions, because OpenSSL and GnuTLS have their own ciphersuite naming conventions that are different from each other and different from the standard, IANA- registered ciphersuite names. The ciphersuite name is intended to be displayed to the user for informative purposes only, and parsing it is not recommended.
Since: 2.70
function.return: The name of the current DTLS ciphersuite, or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_database
function.description:
Gets the certificate database that @conn uses to verify peer certificates. See g_dtls_connection_set_database().
Since: 2.48
function.return: the certificate database that @conn uses or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_interaction
function.description:
Get the object that will be used to interact with the user. It will be used for things like prompting the user for passwords. If %NULL is returned, then no user interaction will occur for this connection.
Since: 2.48
function.return: The interaction object.

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_negotiated_protocol
function.description:
Gets the name of the application-layer protocol negotiated during the handshake.
If the peer did not use the ALPN extension, or did not advertise a protocol that matched one of @conn's protocols, or the TLS backend does not support ALPN, then this will be %NULL. See g_dtls_connection_set_advertised_protocols().
Since: 2.60
function.return: the negotiated protocol, or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_peer_certificate
function.description:
Gets @conn's peer's certificate after the handshake has completed or failed. (It is not set during the emission of #GDtlsConnection::accept-certificate.)
Since: 2.48
function.return: @conn's peer's certificate, or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_peer_certificate_errors
function.description:
Gets the errors associated with validating @conn's peer's certificate, after the handshake has completed or failed. (It is not set during the emission of #GDtlsConnection::accept-certificate.)
Since: 2.48
function.return: @conn's peer's certificate errors

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_protocol_version
function.description:
Returns the current DTLS protocol version, which may be %G_TLS_PROTOCOL_VERSION_UNKNOWN if the connection has not handshaked, or has been closed, or if the TLS backend has implemented a protocol version that is not a recognized #GTlsProtocolVersion.
Since: 2.70
function.return: The current DTLS protocol version

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_rehandshake_mode
function.description:
Gets @conn rehandshaking mode. See g_dtls_connection_set_rehandshake_mode() for details.
Since: 2.48
Deprecated: 2.64. Changing the rehandshake mode is no longer required for compatibility. Also, rehandshaking has been removed from the TLS protocol in TLS 1.3.
function.return: %G_TLS_REHANDSHAKE_SAFELY

function.name: g_dtls_connection_get_require_close_notify
function.description:
Tests whether or not @conn expects a proper TLS close notification when the connection is closed. See g_dtls_connection_set_require_close_notify() for details.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE if @conn requires a proper TLS close notification.

function.name: g_dtls_connection_handshake
function.description:
Attempts a TLS handshake on @conn.
On the client side, it is never necessary to call this method; although the connection needs to perform a handshake after connecting, #GDtlsConnection will handle this for you automatically when you try to send or receive data on the connection. You can call g_dtls_connection_handshake() manually if you want to know whether the initial handshake succeeded or failed (as opposed to just immediately trying to use @conn to read or write, in which case, if it fails, it may not be possible to tell if it failed before or after completing the handshake), but beware that servers may reject client authentication after the handshake has completed, so a successful handshake does not indicate the connection will be usable.
Likewise, on the server side, although a handshake is necessary at the beginning of the communication, you do not need to call this function explicitly unless you want clearer error reporting.
Previously, calling g_dtls_connection_handshake() after the initial handshake would trigger a rehandshake; however, this usage was deprecated in GLib 2.60 because rehandshaking was removed from the TLS protocol in TLS 1.3. Since GLib 2.64, calling this function after the initial handshake will no longer do anything.
#GDtlsConnection::accept_certificate may be emitted during the handshake.
Since: 2.48
function.return: success or failure

function.name: g_dtls_connection_handshake_async
function.description:
Asynchronously performs a TLS handshake on @conn. See g_dtls_connection_handshake() for more information.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the handshake is complete

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: g_dtls_connection_handshake_finish
function.description:
Finish an asynchronous TLS handshake operation. See g_dtls_connection_handshake() for more information.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure, in which case @error will be set.

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_advertised_protocols
function.description:
Sets the list of application-layer protocols to advertise that the caller is willing to speak on this connection. The Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation (ALPN) extension will be used to negotiate a compatible protocol with the peer; use g_dtls_connection_get_negotiated_protocol() to find the negotiated protocol after the handshake. Specifying %NULL for the the value of @protocols will disable ALPN negotiation.
See [IANA TLS ALPN Protocol IDs](https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values/tls-extensiontype-values.xhtml#alpn-protocol-ids) for a list of registered protocol IDs.
Since: 2.60

parameter.name: protocols
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated array of ALPN protocol names (eg, "http/1.1", "h2"), or %NULL

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_certificate
function.description:
This sets the certificate that @conn will present to its peer during the TLS handshake. For a #GDtlsServerConnection, it is mandatory to set this, and that will normally be done at construct time.
For a #GDtlsClientConnection, this is optional. If a handshake fails with %G_TLS_ERROR_CERTIFICATE_REQUIRED, that means that the server requires a certificate, and if you try connecting again, you should call this method first. You can call g_dtls_client_connection_get_accepted_cas() on the failed connection to get a list of Certificate Authorities that the server will accept certificates from.
(It is also possible that a server will allow the connection with or without a certificate; in that case, if you don't provide a certificate, you can tell that the server requested one by the fact that g_dtls_client_connection_get_accepted_cas() will return non-%NULL.)
Since: 2.48

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_database
function.description:
Sets the certificate database that is used to verify peer certificates. This is set to the default database by default. See g_tls_backend_get_default_database(). If set to %NULL, then peer certificate validation will always set the %G_TLS_CERTIFICATE_UNKNOWN_CA error (meaning #GDtlsConnection::accept-certificate will always be emitted on client-side connections, unless that bit is not set in #GDtlsClientConnection:validation-flags).
There are nonintuitive security implications when using a non-default database. See #GDtlsConnection:database for details.
Since: 2.48

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_interaction
function.description:
Set the object that will be used to interact with the user. It will be used for things like prompting the user for passwords.
The @interaction argument will normally be a derived subclass of #GTlsInteraction. %NULL can also be provided if no user interaction should occur for this connection.
Since: 2.48

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_rehandshake_mode
function.description:
Since GLib 2.64, changing the rehandshake mode is no longer supported and will have no effect. With TLS 1.3, rehandshaking has been removed from the TLS protocol, replaced by separate post-handshake authentication and rekey operations.
Since: 2.48
Deprecated: 2.60. Changing the rehandshake mode is no longer required for compatibility. Also, rehandshaking has been removed from the TLS protocol in TLS 1.3.

function.name: g_dtls_connection_set_require_close_notify
function.description:
Sets whether or not @conn expects a proper TLS close notification before the connection is closed. If this is %TRUE (the default), then @conn will expect to receive a TLS close notification from its peer before the connection is closed, and will return a %G_TLS_ERROR_EOF error if the connection is closed without proper notification (since this may indicate a network error, or man-in-the-middle attack).
In some protocols, the application will know whether or not the connection was closed cleanly based on application-level data (because the application-level data includes a length field, or is somehow self-delimiting); in this case, the close notify is redundant and may be omitted. You can use g_dtls_connection_set_require_close_notify() to tell @conn to allow an "unannounced" connection close, in which case the close will show up as a 0-length read, as in a non-TLS #GDatagramBased, and it is up to the application to check that the data has been fully received.
Note that this only affects the behavior when the peer closes the connection; when the application calls g_dtls_connection_close_async() on @conn itself, this will send a close notification regardless of the setting of this property. If you explicitly want to do an unclean close, you can close @conn's #GDtlsConnection:base-socket rather than closing @conn itself.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: require_close_notify
parameter.parameter_description: whether or not to require close notification

function.name: g_dtls_connection_shutdown
function.description:
Shut down part or all of a DTLS connection.
If @shutdown_read is %TRUE then the receiving side of the connection is shut down, and further reading is disallowed. Subsequent calls to g_datagram_based_receive_messages() will return %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED.
If @shutdown_write is %TRUE then the sending side of the connection is shut down, and further writing is disallowed. Subsequent calls to g_datagram_based_send_messages() will return %G_IO_ERROR_CLOSED.
It is allowed for both @shutdown_read and @shutdown_write to be TRUE — this is equivalent to calling g_dtls_connection_close().
If @cancellable is cancelled, the #GDtlsConnection may be left partially-closed and any pending untransmitted data may be lost. Call g_dtls_connection_shutdown() again to complete closing the #GDtlsConnection.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: shutdown_read
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to stop reception of incoming datagrams

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_dtls_connection_shutdown_async
function.description:
Asynchronously shut down part or all of the DTLS connection. See g_dtls_connection_shutdown() for more information.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: shutdown_read
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to stop reception of incoming datagrams

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: callback to call when the shutdown operation is complete

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to the callback function

function.name: g_dtls_connection_shutdown_finish
function.description:
Finish an asynchronous TLS shutdown operation. See g_dtls_connection_shutdown() for more information.
Since: 2.48
function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure, in which case @error will be set

function.name: g_dtls_server_connection_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GDtlsServerConnection wrapping @base_socket.
Since: 2.48

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: #GError for error reporting, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: the new #GDtlsServerConnection, or %NULL on error

function.name: g_emblem_get_icon
function.description:
Gives back the icon from @emblem.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: emblem
parameter.parameter_description: a #GEmblem from which the icon should be extracted.

function.return: a #GIcon. The returned object belongs to the emblem and should not be modified or freed.

function.name: g_emblem_get_origin
function.description:
Gets the origin of the emblem.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the origin of the emblem

function.name: g_emblem_new
function.description:
Creates a new emblem for @icon.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a new #GEmblem.

function.name: g_emblem_new_with_origin
function.description:
Creates a new emblem for @icon.
Since: 2.18

parameter.name: origin
parameter.parameter_description: a GEmblemOrigin enum defining the emblem's origin

function.return: a new #GEmblem.

function.name: g_emblemed_icon_add_emblem
function.description:
Adds @emblem to the #GList of #GEmblems.
Since: 2.18

function.name: g_emblemed_icon_clear_emblems
function.description:
Removes all the emblems from @icon.
Since: 2.28

function.name: g_emblemed_icon_get_emblems
function.description:
Gets the list of emblems for the @icon.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a #GList of #GEmblems that is owned by @emblemed

function.name: g_emblemed_icon_get_icon
function.description:
Gets the main icon for @emblemed.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a #GIcon that is owned by @emblemed

function.name: g_emblemed_icon_new
function.description:
Creates a new emblemed icon for @icon with the emblem @emblem.
Since: 2.18
function.return: a new #GIcon

function.name: g_file_append_to
function.description:
Gets an output stream for appending data to the file. If the file doesn't already exist it is created.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass %G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error. If the file is a directory the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
function.return: a #GFileOutputStream, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_append_to_async
function.description:
Asynchronously opens @file for appending.
For more details, see g_file_append_to() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_append_to_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_append_to_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous file append operation started with g_file_append_to_async().
function.return: a valid #GFileOutputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_add
function.description: Adds a new attribute with @name to the @list, setting its @type and @flags.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the attribute to add.

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_dup
function.description: Makes a duplicate of a file attribute info list.
function.return: a copy of the given @list.

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_lookup
function.description: Gets the file attribute with the name @name from @list.

parameter.name: name
parameter.parameter_description: the name of the attribute to look up.

function.return: a #GFileAttributeInfo for the @name, or %NULL if an attribute isn't found.

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_new
function.description: Creates a new file attribute info list.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeInfoList.

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_ref
function.description: References a file attribute info list.
function.return: #GFileAttributeInfoList or %NULL on error.

function.name: g_file_attribute_info_list_unref
function.description: Removes a reference from the given @list. If the reference count falls to zero, the @list is deleted.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_enumerate_namespace
function.description:
Checks if the matcher will match all of the keys in a given namespace. This will always return %TRUE if a wildcard character is in use (e.g. if matcher was created with "standard::*" and @ns is "standard", or if matcher was created using "*" and namespace is anything.)
TODO: this is awkwardly worded.

parameter.name: ns
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a file attribute namespace.

function.return: %TRUE if the matcher matches all of the entries in the given @ns, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_enumerate_next
function.description: Gets the next matched attribute from a #GFileAttributeMatcher.
function.return: a string containing the next attribute or, %NULL if no more attribute exist.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_matches
function.description: Checks if an attribute will be matched by an attribute matcher. If the matcher was created with the "*" matching string, this function will always return %TRUE.
function.return: %TRUE if @attribute matches @matcher. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_matches_only
function.description: Checks if an attribute matcher only matches a given attribute. Always returns %FALSE if "*" was used when creating the matcher.
function.return: %TRUE if the matcher only matches @attribute. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_new
function.description:
Creates a new file attribute matcher, which matches attributes against a given string. #GFileAttributeMatchers are reference counted structures, and are created with a reference count of 1. If the number of references falls to 0, the #GFileAttributeMatcher is automatically destroyed.
The @attributes string should be formatted with specific keys separated from namespaces with a double colon. Several "namespace::key" strings may be concatenated with a single comma (e.g. "standard::type,standard::is-hidden"). The wildcard "*" may be used to match all keys and namespaces, or "namespace::*" will match all keys in a given namespace.
## Examples of file attribute matcher strings and results
- `"*"`: matches all attributes. - `"standard::is-hidden"`: matches only the key is-hidden in the standard namespace. - `"standard::type,unix::*"`: matches the type key in the standard namespace and all keys in the unix namespace.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeMatcher

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_ref
function.description: References a file attribute matcher.
function.return: a #GFileAttributeMatcher.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_subtract
function.description:
Subtracts all attributes of @subtract from @matcher and returns a matcher that supports those attributes.
Note that currently it is not possible to remove a single attribute when the @matcher matches the whole namespace - or remove a namespace or attribute when the matcher matches everything. This is a limitation of the current implementation, but may be fixed in the future.
function.return: A file attribute matcher matching all attributes of @matcher that are not matched by @subtract

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_to_string
function.description:
Prints what the matcher is matching against. The format will be equal to the format passed to g_file_attribute_matcher_new(). The output however, might not be identical, as the matcher may decide to use a different order or omit needless parts.
Since: 2.32
function.return: a string describing the attributes the matcher matches against or %NULL if @matcher was %NULL.

function.name: g_file_attribute_matcher_unref
function.description: Unreferences @matcher. If the reference count falls below 1, the @matcher is automatically freed.

function.name: g_file_attribute_value_dup
function.description: Duplicates a file attribute.
function.return: a duplicate of the @other.

function.name: g_file_attribute_value_set
function.description: Sets an attribute's value from another attribute.

parameter.name: attr
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFileAttributeValue to set the value in.

parameter.name: new_value
parameter.parameter_description: a #GFileAttributeValue to get the value from.

function.name: g_file_build_attribute_list_for_copy
function.description:
Prepares the file attribute query string for copying to @file.
This function prepares an attribute query string to be passed to g_file_query_info() to get a list of attributes normally copied with the file (see g_file_copy_attributes() for the detailed description). This function is used by the implementation of g_file_copy_attributes() and is useful when one needs to query and set the attributes in two stages (e.g., for recursive move of a directory).
Since: 2.68
function.return: an attribute query string for g_file_query_info(), or %NULL if an error occurs.

function.name: g_file_copy
function.description:
Copies the file @source to the location specified by @destination. Can not handle recursive copies of directories.
If the flag %G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is specified an already existing @destination file is overwritten.
If the flag %G_FILE_COPY_NOFOLLOW_SYMLINKS is specified then symlinks will be copied as symlinks, otherwise the target of the @source symlink will be copied.
If the flag %G_FILE_COPY_ALL_METADATA is specified then all the metadata that is possible to copy is copied, not just the default subset (which, for instance, does not include the owner, see #GFileInfo).
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If @progress_callback is not %NULL, then the operation can be monitored by setting this to a #GFileProgressCallback function. @progress_callback_data will be passed to this function. It is guaranteed that this callback will be called after all data has been transferred with the total number of bytes copied during the operation.
If the @source file does not exist, then the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error is returned, independent on the status of the @destination.
If %G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is not specified and the target exists, then the error %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS is returned.
If trying to overwrite a file over a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_IS_DIRECTORY error is returned. If trying to overwrite a directory with a directory the %G_IO_ERROR_WOULD_MERGE error is returned.
If the source is a directory and the target does not exist, or %G_FILE_COPY_OVERWRITE is specified and the target is a file, then the %G_IO_ERROR_WOULD_RECURSE error is returned.
If you are interested in copying the #GFile object itself (not the on-disk file), see g_file_dup().

parameter.name: progress_callback
parameter.parameter_description: function to callback with progress information, or %NULL if progress information is not needed

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_copy_async
function.description:
Copies the file @source to the location specified by @destination asynchronously. For details of the behaviour, see g_file_copy().
If @progress_callback is not %NULL, then that function that will be called just like in g_file_copy(). The callback will run in the default main context of the thread calling g_file_copy_async() — the same context as @callback is run in.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_copy_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: progress_callback
parameter.parameter_description: function to callback with progress information, or %NULL if progress information is not needed

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback

function.name: g_file_copy_attributes
function.description:
Copies the file attributes from @source to @destination.
Normally only a subset of the file attributes are copied, those that are copies in a normal file copy operation (which for instance does not include e.g. owner). However if %G_FILE_COPY_ALL_METADATA is specified in @flags, then all the metadata that is possible to copy is copied. This is useful when implementing move by copy + delete source.
function.return: %TRUE if the attributes were copied successfully, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_copy_finish
function.description: Finishes copying the file started with g_file_copy_async().
function.return: a %TRUE on success, %FALSE on error.

function.name: g_file_create
function.description:
Creates a new file and returns an output stream for writing to it. The file must not already exist.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass %G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If a file or directory with this name already exists the %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS error will be returned. Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error, and if the name is to long %G_IO_ERROR_FILENAME_TOO_LONG will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
function.return: a #GFileOutputStream for the newly created file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_async
function.description:
Asynchronously creates a new file and returns an output stream for writing to it. The file must not already exist.
For more details, see g_file_create() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_create_finish() to get the result of the operation.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_create_finish
function.description: Finishes an asynchronous file create operation started with g_file_create_async().
function.return: a #GFileOutputStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite
function.description:
Creates a new file and returns a stream for reading and writing to it. The file must not already exist.
By default files created are generally readable by everyone, but if you pass %G_FILE_CREATE_PRIVATE in @flags the file will be made readable only to the current user, to the level that is supported on the target filesystem.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If a file or directory with this name already exists, the %G_IO_ERROR_EXISTS error will be returned. Some file systems don't allow all file names, and may return an %G_IO_ERROR_INVALID_FILENAME error, and if the name is too long, %G_IO_ERROR_FILENAME_TOO_LONG will be returned. Other errors are possible too, and depend on what kind of filesystem the file is on.
Note that in many non-local file cases read and write streams are not supported, so make sure you really need to do read and write streaming, rather than just opening for reading or writing.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileIOStream for the newly created file, or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite_async
function.description:
Asynchronously creates a new file and returns a stream for reading and writing to it. The file must not already exist.
For more details, see g_file_create_readwrite() which is the synchronous version of this call.
When the operation is finished, @callback will be called. You can then call g_file_create_readwrite_finish() to get the result of the operation.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_create_readwrite_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous file create operation started with g_file_create_readwrite_async().
Since: 2.22
function.return: a #GFileIOStream or %NULL on error. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_file_delete
function.return: %TRUE if the file was deleted. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_delete_async
function.description:
Asynchronously delete a file. If the @file is a directory, it will only be deleted if it is empty. This has the same semantics as g_unlink().
Since: 2.34

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_delete_finish
function.description:
Finishes deleting a file started with g_file_delete_async().
Since: 2.34
function.return: %TRUE if the file was deleted. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_descriptor_based_get_fd
function.description:
Gets the underlying file descriptor.
Since: 2.24
function.return: The file descriptor

function.name: g_file_dup
function.description:
Duplicates a #GFile handle. This operation does not duplicate the actual file or directory represented by the #GFile; see g_file_copy() if attempting to copy a file.
g_file_dup() is useful when a second handle is needed to the same underlying file, for use in a separate thread (#GFile is not thread-safe). For use within the same thread, use g_object_ref() to increment the existing object’s reference count.
This call does no blocking I/O.
function.return: a new #GFile that is a duplicate of the given #GFile.

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable
function.description:
Starts an asynchronous eject on a mountable. When this operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user_user data, and the operation can be finalized with g_file_eject_mountable_finish().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation() instead.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous eject operation started by g_file_eject_mountable().
Deprecated: 2.22: Use g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish() instead.
function.return: %TRUE if the @file was ejected successfully. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation
function.description:
Starts an asynchronous eject on a mountable. When this operation has completed, @callback will be called with @user_user data, and the operation can be finalized with g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish().
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation, or %NULL to avoid user interaction

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a #GAsyncReadyCallback to call when the request is satisfied

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: the data to pass to callback function

function.name: g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation_finish
function.description:
Finishes an asynchronous eject operation started by g_file_eject_mountable_with_operation().
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if the @file was ejected successfully. %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_file_enumerate_children
function.description:
Gets the requested information about the files in a directory. The result is a #GFileEnumerator object that will give out #GFileInfo objects for all the files in the directory.
The @attributes value is a string that specifies the file attributes that should be gathered. It is not an error if it's not possible to read a particular requested attribute from a file - it just won't be set. @attributes should be a comma-separated list of attributes or attribute wildcards. The wildcard "*" means all attributes, and a wildcard like "standard::*" means all attributes in the standard namespace. An example attribute query be "standard::*,owner::user". The standard attributes are available as defines, like %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_NAME. %G_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_STANDARD_NAME should always be specified if you plan to call g_file_enumerator_get_child() or g_file_enumerator_iterate() on the returned enumerator.
If @cancellable is not %NULL, then the operation can be cancelled by triggering the cancellable object from another thread. If the operation was cancelled, the error %G_IO_ERROR_CANCELLED will be returned.
If the file does not exist, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_FOUND error will be returned. If the file is not a directory, the %G_IO_ERROR_NOT_DIRECTORY error will be returned. Other errors are possible too.
