function.return: the #GUnixFDList from @message

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDMessage containing an empty file descriptor list.
Since: 2.22
function.return: a new #GUnixFDMessage

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_new_with_fd_list
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixFDMessage containing @list.
Since: 2.24
function.return: a new #GUnixFDMessage

function.name: g_unix_fd_message_steal_fds
function.description:
Returns the array of file descriptors that is contained in this object.
After this call, the descriptors are no longer contained in @message. Further calls will return an empty list (unless more descriptors have been added).
The return result of this function must be freed with g_free(). The caller is also responsible for closing all of the file descriptors.
If @length is non-%NULL then it is set to the number of file descriptors in the returned array. The returned array is also terminated with -1.
This function never returns %NULL. In case there are no file descriptors contained in @message, an empty array is returned.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: length
parameter.parameter_description: pointer to the length of the returned array, or %NULL

function.return: an array of file descriptors

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_get_close_fd
function.description:
Returns whether the file descriptor of @stream will be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20
function.return: %TRUE if the file descriptor is closed when done

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_get_fd
function.description:
Return the UNIX file descriptor that the stream reads from.
Since: 2.20
function.return: The file descriptor of @stream

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixInputStream for the given @fd.
If @close_fd is %TRUE, the file descriptor will be closed when the stream is closed.

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.return: a new #GUnixInputStream

function.name: g_unix_input_stream_set_close_fd
function.description:
Sets whether the file descriptor of @stream shall be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.name: g_unix_is_mount_path_system_internal
function.description:
Determines if @mount_path is considered an implementation of the OS.
This is primarily used for hiding mountable and mounted volumes that only are used in the OS and has little to no relevance to the casual user.
function.return: true if @mount_path is considered an implementation detail of the OS; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_is_system_device_path
function.description:
Determines if @device_path is considered a block device path which is only used in implementation of the OS.
This is primarily used for hiding mounted volumes that are intended as APIs for programs to read, and system administrators at a shell; rather than something that should, for example, appear in a GUI. For example, the Linux `/proc` filesystem.
The list of device paths considered ‘system’ ones may change over time.
Since: 2.56
function.return: true if @device_path is considered an implementation detail of the OS; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_is_system_fs_type
function.description:
Determines if @fs_type is considered a type of file system which is only used in implementation of the OS.
This is primarily used for hiding mounted volumes that are intended as APIs for programs to read, and system administrators at a shell; rather than something that should, for example, appear in a GUI. For example, the Linux `/proc` filesystem.
The list of file system types considered ‘system’ ones may change over time.
Since: 2.56

parameter.name: fs_type
parameter.parameter_description: a file system type, e.g. `procfs` or `tmpfs`

function.return: true if @fs_type is considered an implementation detail of the OS; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_at
function.description:
Gets a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] for a given mount path.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a Unix timestamp for checking if the mounts have changed since with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
If more mounts have the same mount path, the last matching mount is returned.
This will return `NULL` if there is no mount point at @mount_path.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [func@GioUnix.MountEntry.at] instead.

parameter.name: mount_path
parameter.parameter_description: path for a possible Unix mount

function.return: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_compare
function.description:
Compares two Unix mounts.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [method@GioUnix.MountEntry.compare] instead.
function.return: `1`, `0` or `-1` if @mount1 is greater than, equal to, or less than @mount2, respectively

function.name: g_unix_mount_copy
function.description:
Makes a copy of @mount_entry.
Since: 2.54 Deprecated: 2.84: Use [method@GioUnix.MountEntry.copy] instead.
function.return: a new [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entries_changed_since
function.description:
Checks if the Unix mounts have changed since a given Unix time.
This can only work reliably if a [class@GioUnix.MountMonitor] is running in the process, otherwise changes in the mount entries file (such as `/proc/self/mountinfo` on Linux) cannot be detected and, as a result, this function has to conservatively always return `TRUE`.
It is more efficient to use [signal@GioUnix.MountMonitor::mounts-changed] to be signalled of changes to the mount entries, rather than polling using this function. This function is more appropriate for infrequently determining cache validity.
Since 2.84
function.return: true if the mounts have changed since @time; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_entries_get
function.description:
Gets a list of [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] instances representing the Unix mounts.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with the mount timestamp, allowing for checking if the mounts have changed with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
Since: 2.84
function.return: a list of the Unix mounts

function.name: g_unix_mount_entries_get_from_file
function.description:
Gets an array of [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]s containing the Unix mounts listed in @table_path.
This is a generalized version of [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get], mainly intended for internal testing use. Note that [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get] may parse multiple hierarchical table files, so this function is not a direct superset of its functionality.
If there is an error reading or parsing the file, `NULL` will be returned and both out parameters will be set to `0`.
Since: 2.84

parameter.name: table_path
parameter.parameter_description: path to the mounts table file (for example `/proc/self/mountinfo`)

parameter.name: time_read_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the modification time of @table_path

parameter.name: n_entries_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of mount entries returned

function.return: mount entries, or `NULL` if there was an error loading them

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_at
function.description:
Gets a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] for a given mount path.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a Unix timestamp for checking if the mounts have changed since with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
If more mounts have the same mount path, the last matching mount is returned.
This will return `NULL` if there is no mount point at @mount_path.
Since: 2.84

parameter.name: mount_path
parameter.parameter_description: path for a possible Unix mount

function.return: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_compare
function.description:
Compares two Unix mounts.
Since: 2.84
function.return: `1`, `0` or `-1` if @mount1 is greater than, equal to, or less than @mount2, respectively

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_copy
function.description:
Makes a copy of @mount_entry.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a new [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_for
function.description:
Gets a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] for a given file path.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a Unix timestamp for checking if the mounts have changed since with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
If more mounts have the same mount path, the last matching mount is returned.
This will return `NULL` if looking up the mount entry fails, if @file_path doesn’t exist or there is an I/O error.
Since: 2.84

parameter.name: file_path
parameter.parameter_description: file path on some Unix mount

function.return: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_free
function.description:
Frees a Unix mount.
Since: 2.84

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_get_device_path
function.description:
Gets the device path for a Unix mount.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a string containing the device path

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_get_fs_type
function.description:
Gets the filesystem type for the Unix mount.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a string containing the file system type

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_get_mount_path
function.description:
Gets the mount path for a Unix mount.
Since: 2.84

parameter.name: mount_entry
parameter.parameter_description: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] to get the mount path for

function.return: the mount path for @mount_entry

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_get_options
function.description:
Gets a comma separated list of mount options for the Unix mount.
For example: `rw,relatime,seclabel,data=ordered`.
This is similar to [method@GioUnix.MountPoint.get_options], but it takes a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] as an argument.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a string containing the options, or `NULL` if not available.

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_get_root_path
function.description:
Gets the root of the mount within the filesystem. This is useful e.g. for mounts created by bind operation, or btrfs subvolumes.
For example, the root path is equal to `/` for a mount created by `mount /dev/sda1 /mnt/foo` and `/bar` for `mount --bind /mnt/foo/bar /mnt/bar`.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a string containing the root, or `NULL` if not supported

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_can_eject
function.description:
Guesses whether a Unix mount entry can be ejected.
Since: 2.84
function.return: true if @mount_entry is deemed to be ejectable; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_icon
function.description:
Guesses the icon of a Unix mount entry.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a [iface@Gio.Icon]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_name
function.description:
Guesses the name of a Unix mount entry.
The result is a translated string.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a newly allocated translated string

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_should_display
function.description:
Guesses whether a Unix mount entry should be displayed in the UI.
Since: 2.84
function.return: true if @mount_entry is deemed to be displayable; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_symbolic_icon
function.description:
Guesses the symbolic icon of a Unix mount entry.
Since: 2.84
function.return: a [iface@Gio.Icon]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_guess_type
function.description:
Guesses the type of a Unix mount entry.
If the mount type cannot be determined, returns [enum@GioUnix.MountType.UNKNOWN].
function.return: a [enum@GioUnix.MountType]

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_is_readonly
function.description:
Checks if a Unix mount is mounted read only.
Since: 2.84
function.return: true if @mount_entry is read only; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_entry_is_system_internal
function.description:
Checks if a Unix mount is a system mount.
This is the Boolean OR of [func@GioUnix.is_system_fs_type], [func@GioUnix.is_system_device_path] and [func@GioUnix.is_mount_path_system_internal] on @mount_entry’s properties.
The definition of what a ‘system’ mount entry is may change over time as new file system types and device paths are ignored.
Since: 2.84
function.return: true if the Unix mount is for a system path; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_for
function.description:
Gets a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] for a given file path.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a Unix timestamp for checking if the mounts have changed since with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
If more mounts have the same mount path, the last matching mount is returned.
This will return `NULL` if looking up the mount entry fails, if @file_path doesn’t exist or there is an I/O error.
Since: 2.52 Deprecated: 2.84: Use [func@GioUnix.MountEntry.for] instead.

parameter.name: file_path
parameter.parameter_description: file path on some Unix mount

function.return: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]

function.name: g_unix_mount_free
function.description:
Frees a Unix mount.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [method@GioUnix.MountEntry.free] instead.

Gets the device path for a Unix mount.

function.name: g_unix_mount_get_fs_type

Gets the filesystem type for the Unix mount.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [method@GioUnix.MountEntry.get_fs_type] instead.
function.return: a string containing the file system type

function.name: g_unix_mount_get_mount_path
function.description:
Gets the mount path for a Unix mount.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [method@GioUnix.MountEntry.get_mount_path] instead.

parameter.name: mount_entry
parameter.parameter_description: a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] to get the mount path for

Gets a comma separated list of mount options for the Unix mount.
For example: `rw,relatime,seclabel,data=ordered`.
This is similar to [method@GioUnix.MountPoint.get_options], but it takes a [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] as an argument.

Gets the root of the mount within the filesystem.
This is useful e.g. for mounts created by bind operation, or btrfs subvolumes.

function.name: g_unix_mount_monitor_get
function.description:
Gets the [class@GioUnix.MountMonitor] for the current thread-default main context.
The mount monitor can be used to monitor for changes to the list of mounted filesystems as well as the list of mount points (ie: fstab entries).
You must only call [method@GObject.Object.unref] on the return value from under the same main context as you called this function.
Since: 2.44
function.return: the [class@GioUnix.MountMonitor]

function.name: g_unix_mount_monitor_new
function.description:
Deprecated alias for [func@GioUnix.MountMonitor.get].
This function was never a true constructor, which is why it was renamed.
Deprecated: 2.44: Use [func@GioUnix.MountMonitor.get] instead.
function.return: a [class@GioUnix.MountMonitor]

function.name: g_unix_mount_monitor_set_rate_limit
function.description:
This function does nothing.
Before 2.44, this was a partially-effective way of controlling the rate at which events would be reported under some uncommon circumstances. Since @mount_monitor is a singleton, it also meant that calling this function would have side effects for other users of the monitor.
Since: 2.18 Deprecated: 2.44: This function does nothing. Don’t call it.

parameter.name: limit_msec
parameter.parameter_description: a integer with the limit (in milliseconds) to poll for changes

If @time_read is set, it will be filled with a Unix timestamp for checking if the mount points have changed since with [func@GioUnix.mount_points_changed_since].
If more mount points have the same mount path, the last matching mount point is returned.

Guesses the type of a Unix mount point.

function.description: Checks if a Unix mount point is a loopback device.

function.name: g_unix_mount_point_is_readonly
function.description: Checks if a Unix mount point is read only.

function.description: Checks if a Unix mount point is mountable by the user.

function.name: g_unix_mount_points_changed_since
function.description:
Checks if the Unix mount points have changed since a given Unix time.
Unlike [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since], this function can work reliably without a [class@GioUnix.MountMonitor] running, as it accesses the static mount point information (such as `/etc/fstab` on Linux), which has a valid modification time.
It is more efficient to use [signal@GioUnix.MountMonitor::mountpoints-changed] to be signalled of changes to the mount points, rather than polling using this function. This function is more appropriate for infrequently determining cache validity.
function.return: true if the mount points have changed since @time; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mount_points_get
function.description:
Gets a list of [struct@GioUnix.MountPoint] instances representing the Unix mount points.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with the mount timestamp, allowing for checking if the mounts have changed with [func@GioUnix.mount_points_changed_since].
function.return: a list of the Unix mount points

function.name: g_unix_mount_points_get_from_file
function.description:
Gets an array of [struct@GioUnix.MountPoint]s containing the Unix mount points listed in @table_path.
This is a generalized version of [func@GioUnix.mount_points_get], mainly intended for internal testing use. Note that [func@GioUnix.mount_points_get] may parse multiple hierarchical table files, so this function is not a direct superset of its functionality.
If there is an error reading or parsing the file, `NULL` will be returned and both out parameters will be set to `0`.
Since: 2.82

parameter.name: table_path
parameter.parameter_description: path to the mount points table file (for example `/etc/fstab`)

parameter.name: time_read_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the modification time of @table_path

parameter.name: n_points_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of mount points returned

function.return: mount points, or `NULL` if there was an error loading them

function.name: g_unix_mounts_changed_since
function.description:
Checks if the Unix mounts have changed since a given Unix time.
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since] instead.
function.return: true if the mounts have changed since @time; false otherwise

function.name: g_unix_mounts_get
function.description:
Gets a list of [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry] instances representing the Unix mounts.
If @time_read is set, it will be filled with the mount timestamp, allowing for checking if the mounts have changed with [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_changed_since].
Deprecated: 2.84: Use [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get] instead.
function.return: a list of the Unix mounts

function.name: g_unix_mounts_get_from_file
function.description:
Gets an array of [struct@GioUnix.MountEntry]s containing the Unix mounts listed in @table_path.
This is a generalized version of [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get], mainly intended for internal testing use. Note that [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get] may parse multiple hierarchical table files, so this function is not a direct superset of its functionality.
If there is an error reading or parsing the file, `NULL` will be returned and both out parameters will be set to `0`.
Since: 2.82 Deprecated: 2.84: Use [func@GioUnix.mount_entries_get_from_file] instead.

parameter.name: table_path
parameter.parameter_description: path to the mounts table file (for example `/proc/self/mountinfo`)

parameter.name: time_read_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the modification time of @table_path

parameter.name: n_entries_out
parameter.parameter_description: return location for the number of mount entries returned

function.return: mount entries, or `NULL` if there was an error loading them

function.name: g_unix_output_stream_get_close_fd
function.description:
Returns whether the file descriptor of @stream will be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20
function.return: %TRUE if the file descriptor is closed when done

function.name: g_unix_output_stream_get_fd
function.description:
Return the UNIX file descriptor that the stream writes to.
Since: 2.20
function.return: The file descriptor of @stream

function.name: g_unix_output_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixOutputStream for the given @fd.
If @close_fd, is %TRUE, the file descriptor will be closed when the output stream is destroyed.

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.return: a new #GOutputStream

function.name: g_unix_output_stream_set_close_fd
function.description:
Sets whether the file descriptor of @stream shall be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.20

parameter.name: close_fd
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the file descriptor when done

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_abstract_names_supported
function.description:
Checks if abstract UNIX domain socket names are supported.
Since: 2.22
function.return: %TRUE if supported, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_address_type
function.description:
Gets @address's type.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a #GUnixSocketAddressType

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_is_abstract
function.description:
Tests if @address is abstract.
Since: 2.22
Deprecated: Use g_unix_socket_address_get_address_type()
function.return: %TRUE if the address is abstract, %FALSE otherwise

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_path
function.description:
Gets @address's path, or for abstract sockets the "name".
Guaranteed to be zero-terminated, but an abstract socket may contain embedded zeros, and thus you should use g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len() to get the true length of this string.
Since: 2.22
function.return: the path for @address

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len
function.description:
Gets the length of @address's path.
For details, see g_unix_socket_address_get_path().
Since: 2.22
function.return: the length of the path

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixSocketAddress for @path.
To create abstract socket addresses, on systems that support that, use g_unix_socket_address_new_abstract().
Since: 2.22
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new_abstract
function.description:
Creates a new %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED #GUnixSocketAddress for @path.
Deprecated: Use g_unix_socket_address_new_with_type().
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.name: g_unix_socket_address_new_with_type
function.description:
Creates a new #GUnixSocketAddress of type @type with name @path.
If @type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_PATH, this is equivalent to calling g_unix_socket_address_new().
If @type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ANONYMOUS, @path and @path_len will be ignored.
If @path_type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT, then @path_len bytes of @path will be copied to the socket's path, and only those bytes will be considered part of the name. (If @path_len is -1, then @path is assumed to be NUL-terminated.) For example, if @path was "test", then calling g_socket_address_get_native_size() on the returned socket would return 7 (2 bytes of overhead, 1 byte for the abstract-socket indicator byte, and 4 bytes for the name "test").
If @path_type is %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED, then @path_len bytes of @path will be copied to the socket's path, the rest of the path will be padded with 0 bytes, and the entire zero-padded buffer will be considered the name. (As above, if @path_len is -1, then @path is assumed to be NUL-terminated.) In this case, g_socket_address_get_native_size() will always return the full size of a `struct sockaddr_un`, although g_unix_socket_address_get_path_len() will still return just the length of @path.
%G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT is preferred over %G_UNIX_SOCKET_ADDRESS_ABSTRACT_PADDED for new programs. Of course, when connecting to a server created by another process, you must use the appropriate type corresponding to how that process created its listening socket.
Since: 2.26
function.return: a new #GUnixSocketAddress

function.name: g_vfs_get_default
function.description: Gets the default #GVfs for the system.
function.return: a #GVfs, which will be the local file system #GVfs if no other implementation is available.

function.name: g_vfs_get_file_for_path
function.description: Gets a #GFile for @path.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: a string containing a VFS path.

function.return: a #GFile. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_vfs_get_file_for_uri
function.description:
Gets a #GFile for @uri.
This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operation if the URI is malformed or if the URI scheme is not supported.
function.return: a #GFile. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_vfs_get_local
function.description: Gets the local #GVfs for the system.
function.return: a #GVfs.

function.name: g_vfs_get_supported_uri_schemes
function.description: Gets a list of URI schemes supported by @vfs.
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings. The returned array belongs to GIO and must not be freed or modified.

function.name: g_vfs_is_active
function.description: Checks if the VFS is active.
function.return: %TRUE if construction of the @vfs was successful and it is now active.

function.name: g_vfs_parse_name
function.description: This operation never fails, but the returned object might not support any I/O operations if the @parse_name cannot be parsed by the #GVfs module.

parameter.name: parse_name
parameter.parameter_description: a string to be parsed by the VFS module.

function.return: a #GFile for the given @parse_name. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_vfs_register_uri_scheme
function.description:
Registers @uri_func and @parse_name_func as the #GFile URI and parse name lookup functions for URIs with a scheme matching @scheme. Note that @scheme is registered only within the running application, as opposed to desktop-wide as it happens with GVfs backends.
When a #GFile is requested with an URI containing @scheme (e.g. through g_file_new_for_uri()), @uri_func will be called to allow a custom constructor. The implementation of @uri_func should not be blocking, and must not call g_vfs_register_uri_scheme() or g_vfs_unregister_uri_scheme().
When g_file_parse_name() is called with a parse name obtained from such file, @parse_name_func will be called to allow the #GFile to be created again. In that case, it's responsibility of @parse_name_func to make sure the parse name matches what the custom #GFile implementation returned when g_file_get_parse_name() was previously called. The implementation of @parse_name_func should not be blocking, and must not call g_vfs_register_uri_scheme() or g_vfs_unregister_uri_scheme().
It's an error to call this function twice with the same scheme. To unregister a custom URI scheme, use g_vfs_unregister_uri_scheme().
Since: 2.50

parameter.name: uri_data
parameter.parameter_description: custom data passed to be passed to @uri_func, or %NULL

parameter.name: uri_destroy
parameter.parameter_description: function to be called when unregistering the URI scheme, or when @vfs is disposed, to free the resources used by the URI lookup function

parameter.name: parse_name_data
parameter.parameter_description: custom data passed to be passed to @parse_name_func, or %NULL

parameter.name: parse_name_destroy
parameter.parameter_description: function to be called when unregistering the URI scheme, or when @vfs is disposed, to free the resources used by the parse name lookup function

function.return: %TRUE if @scheme was successfully registered, or %FALSE if a handler for @scheme already exists.

function.name: g_vfs_unregister_uri_scheme
function.description:
Unregisters the URI handler for @scheme previously registered with g_vfs_register_uri_scheme().
Since: 2.50
function.return: %TRUE if @scheme was successfully unregistered, or %FALSE if a handler for @scheme does not exist.

parameter.parameter_description: user data that gets passed to @callback

function.name: g_volume_eject_finish

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store an error, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: %TRUE, %FALSE if operation failed

function.name: g_volume_eject_with_operation
function.description:
Ejects a volume. This is an asynchronous operation, and is finished by calling g_volume_eject_with_operation_finish() with the @volume and #GAsyncResult data returned in the @callback.
Since: 2.22

parameter.name: flags
parameter.parameter_description: flags affecting the unmount if required for eject

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction

function.name: g_volume_enumerate_identifiers
function.description: Gets the kinds of [identifiers](#volume-identifiers) that @volume has. Use g_volume_get_identifier() to obtain the identifiers themselves.
function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of strings containing kinds of identifiers. Use g_strfreev() to free.

function.name: g_volume_get_activation_root
function.description:
Gets the activation root for a #GVolume if it is known ahead of mount time. Returns %NULL otherwise. If not %NULL and if @volume is mounted, then the result of g_mount_get_root() on the #GMount object obtained from g_volume_get_mount() will always either be equal or a prefix of what this function returns. In other words, in code
|[<!-- language="C" --> GMount *mount; GFile *mount_root GFile *volume_activation_root;
mount = g_volume_get_mount (volume); // mounted, so never NULL mount_root = g_mount_get_root (mount); volume_activation_root = g_volume_get_activation_root (volume); // assume not NULL ]| then the expression |[<!-- language="C" --> (g_file_has_prefix (volume_activation_root, mount_root) || g_file_equal (volume_activation_root, mount_root)) ]| will always be %TRUE.
Activation roots are typically used in #GVolumeMonitor implementations to find the underlying mount to shadow, see g_mount_is_shadowed() for more details.
Since: 2.18
function.return: the activation root of @volume or %NULL. Use g_object_unref() to free.

function.name: g_volume_get_drive
function.description: Gets the drive for the @volume.
function.return: a #GDrive or %NULL if @volume is not associated with a drive. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_icon
function.description: Gets the icon for @volume.
function.return: a #GIcon. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_identifier
function.description: Gets the identifier of the given kind for @volume. See the [introduction](#volume-identifiers) for more information about volume identifiers.

parameter.name: kind
parameter.parameter_description: the kind of identifier to return

function.return: a newly allocated string containing the requested identifier, or %NULL if the #GVolume doesn't have this kind of identifier

function.name: g_volume_get_mount
function.description: Gets the mount for the @volume.
function.return: a #GMount or %NULL if @volume isn't mounted. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_name
function.description: Gets the name of @volume.
function.return: the name for the given @volume. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_sort_key
function.description:
Gets the sort key for @volume, if any.
Since: 2.32
function.return: Sorting key for @volume or %NULL if no such key is available

function.name: g_volume_get_symbolic_icon
function.description:
Gets the symbolic icon for @volume.
Since: 2.34
function.return: a #GIcon. The returned object should be unreffed with g_object_unref() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_get_uuid
function.description: Gets the UUID for the @volume. The reference is typically based on the file system UUID for the volume in question and should be considered an opaque string. Returns %NULL if there is no UUID available.
function.return: the UUID for @volume or %NULL if no UUID can be computed. The returned string should be freed with g_free() when no longer needed.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_adopt_orphan_mount
function.description:
This function should be called by any #GVolumeMonitor implementation when a new #GMount object is created that is not associated with a #GVolume object. It must be called just before emitting the @mount_added signal.
If the return value is not %NULL, the caller must associate the returned #GVolume object with the #GMount. This involves returning it in its g_mount_get_volume() implementation. The caller must also listen for the "removed" signal on the returned object and give up its reference when handling that signal
Similarly, if implementing g_volume_monitor_adopt_orphan_mount(), the implementor must take a reference to @mount and return it in its g_volume_get_mount() implemented. Also, the implementor must listen for the "unmounted" signal on @mount and give up its reference upon handling that signal.
There are two main use cases for this function.
One is when implementing a user space file system driver that reads blocks of a block device that is already represented by the native volume monitor (for example a CD Audio file system driver). Such a driver will generate its own #GMount object that needs to be associated with the #GVolume object that represents the volume.
The other is for implementing a #GVolumeMonitor whose sole purpose is to return #GVolume objects representing entries in the users "favorite servers" list or similar.
Deprecated: 2.20: Instead of using this function, #GVolumeMonitor implementations should instead create shadow mounts with the URI of the mount they intend to adopt. See the proxy volume monitor in gvfs for an example of this. Also see g_mount_is_shadowed(), g_mount_shadow() and g_mount_unshadow() functions.

parameter.name: mount
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMount object to find a parent for

function.return: the #GVolume object that is the parent for @mount or %NULL if no wants to adopt the #GMount.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get
function.description: Gets the volume monitor used by gio.
function.return: a reference to the #GVolumeMonitor used by gio. Call g_object_unref() when done with it, after disconnecting any signal handlers.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_connected_drives
function.description:
Gets a list of drives connected to the system.
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().
function.return: a #GList of connected #GDrive objects.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_mount_for_uuid
function.description: Finds a #GMount object by its UUID (see g_mount_get_uuid())
function.return: a #GMount or %NULL if no such mount is available. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_mounts
function.description:
Gets a list of the mounts on the system.
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().
function.return: a #GList of #GMount objects.

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_volume_for_uuid
function.description: Finds a #GVolume object by its UUID (see g_volume_get_uuid())
function.return: a #GVolume or %NULL if no such volume is available. Free the returned object with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_volume_monitor_get_volumes
function.description:
Gets a list of the volumes on the system.
The returned list should be freed with g_list_free(), after its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().
function.return: a #GList of #GVolume objects.

function.name: g_volume_mount
function.description: Mounts a volume. This is an asynchronous operation, and is finished by calling g_volume_mount_finish() with the @volume and #GAsyncResult returned in the @callback.

parameter.name: mount_operation
parameter.parameter_description: a #GMountOperation or %NULL to avoid user interaction

parameter.name: user_data

function.name: g_volume_mount_finish
function.description:
Finishes mounting a volume. If any errors occurred during the operation, @error will be set to contain the errors and %FALSE will be returned.
If the mount operation succeeded, g_volume_get_mount() on @volume is guaranteed to return the mount right after calling this function; there's no need to listen for the 'mount-added' signal on #GVolumeMonitor.

parameter.name: error
parameter.parameter_description: a #GError location to store an error, or %NULL to ignore

function.return: %TRUE, %FALSE if operation failed

function.name: g_volume_should_automount
function.description: Returns whether the volume should be automatically mounted.
function.return: %TRUE if the volume should be automatically mounted

function.name: g_win32_file_sync_stream_new
function.description:
Creates an IStream object backed by a HANDLE.
@stgm_mode should match the mode of the @handle, otherwise the stream might attempt to perform operations that the @handle does not allow. The implementation itself ignores these flags completely, they are only used to report the mode of the stream to third parties.
The stream only does synchronous access and will never return `E_PENDING` on I/O.
The returned stream object should be treated just like any other COM object, and released via `IUnknown_Release()`. its elements have been unreffed with g_object_unref().

parameter.name: handle
parameter.parameter_description: a Win32 HANDLE for a file.

parameter.name: owns_handle
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if newly-created stream owns the handle (and closes it when destroyed)

parameter.name: stgm_mode
parameter.parameter_description: a combination of [STGM constants](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/stg/stgm-constants) that specify the mode with which the stream is opened.

parameter.name: output_hresult
parameter.parameter_description: a HRESULT from the internal COM calls. Will be `S_OK` on success.

function.return: a new IStream object on success, %NULL on failure.

Creates a new #GWin32InputStream for the given @handle.
If @close_handle is %TRUE, the handle will be closed when the stream is closed.
Note that "handle" here means a Win32 HANDLE, not a "file descriptor" as used in the Windows C libraries.

parameter.name: close_handle
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the handle when done

function.return: a new #GWin32InputStream

function.name: g_win32_input_stream_set_close_handle
function.description:
Sets whether the handle of @stream shall be closed when the stream is closed.

function.name: g_win32_output_stream_get_close_handle
function.description:
Returns whether the handle of @stream will be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.26
function.return: %TRUE if the handle is closed when done

function.name: g_win32_output_stream_get_handle
function.description:
Return the Windows handle that the stream writes to.
Since: 2.26
function.return: The handle descriptor of @stream

function.name: g_win32_output_stream_new
function.description:
Creates a new #GWin32OutputStream for the given @handle.
If @close_handle, is %TRUE, the handle will be closed when the output stream is destroyed.
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: close_handle
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to close the handle when done

function.return: a new #GOutputStream

function.description:
Sets whether the handle of @stream shall be closed when the stream is closed.
Since: 2.26

Returns a list of directories for DLL lookups. Can be used with g_win32_registry_key_get_value().

function.description:
Returns a list of directories for DLL lookups. Can be used with g_win32_registry_key_get_value_w().

function.return: a %NULL-terminated array of UTF-16 strings.

function.description:
Erases change indicator of the @key.
Subsequent calls to g_win32_registry_key_has_changed() will return %FALSE until the key is put on watch again by calling g_win32_registry_key_watch() again.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_child
function.description: Opens a @subkey of the @key.

parameter.name: subkey
parameter.parameter_description: name of a child key to open (in UTF-8), relative to @key

function.return: a #GWin32RegistryKey or %NULL if can't be opened. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_child_w
function.description: Opens a @subkey of the @key.

parameter.name: subkey

function.return: a #GWin32RegistryKey or %NULL if can't be opened. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_path
function.description:
Get full path to the key
Since: 2.46
function.return: a full path to the key (in UTF-8), or %NULL if it can't be converted to UTF-8.

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_path_w
function.description:
Get full path to the key
Since: 2.46
function.return: a full path to the key (in UTF-16)

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_value
function.description:
Get data from a value of a key. String data is guaranteed to be appropriately terminated and will be in UTF-8.
When not %NULL, @mui_dll_dirs indicates that `RegLoadMUIStringW()` API should be used instead of the usual `RegQueryValueExW()`. This implies that the value being queried is of type `REG_SZ` or `REG_EXPAND_SZ` (if it is not, the function falls back to `RegQueryValueExW()`), and that this string must undergo special processing (see [`SHLoadIndirectString()` documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/shlwapi/nf-shlwapi-shloadindirectstring) for an explanation on what kinds of strings are processed) to get the result.
If no specific MUI DLL directories need to be used, pass the return value of g_win32_registry_get_os_dirs() as @mui_dll_dirs (as an bonus, the value from g_win32_registry_get_os_dirs() does not add any extra UTF8->UTF16 conversion overhead).
@auto_expand works with @mui_dll_dirs, but only affects the processed string, making it somewhat useless. The unprocessed string is always expanded internally, if its type is `REG_EXPAND_SZ` - there is no need to enable @auto_expand for this to work.
The API for this function changed in GLib 2.66 to add the @mui_dll_dirs argument.
Since: 2.66

parameter.name: mui_dll_dirs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated array of directory names where the OS should look for a DLL indicated in a MUI string, if the DLL path in the string is not absolute

parameter.name: auto_expand
parameter.parameter_description: (in) %TRUE to automatically expand G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_EXPAND_STR to G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_STR.

parameter.name: value_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the value to get (in UTF-8). Empty string means the '(Default)' value.

parameter.name: value_data_size
parameter.parameter_description: size of the buffer pointed by @value_data, in bytes.

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure.

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_get_value_w
function.description:
Get data from a value of a key. String data is guaranteed to be appropriately terminated and will be in UTF-16.
When calling with value_data == NULL (to get data size without getting the data itself) remember that returned size corresponds to possibly unterminated string data (if value is some kind of string), because termination cannot be checked and fixed unless the data is retrieved too.
When not %NULL, @mui_dll_dirs indicates that `RegLoadMUIStringW()` API should be used instead of the usual `RegQueryValueExW()`. This implies that the value being queried is of type `REG_SZ` or `REG_EXPAND_SZ` (if it is not, the function falls back to `RegQueryValueExW()`), and that this string must undergo special processing (see [`SHLoadIndirectString()` documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/shlwapi/nf-shlwapi-shloadindirectstring) for an explanation on what kinds of strings are processed) to get the result.
If no specific MUI DLL directories need to be used, pass the return value of g_win32_registry_get_os_dirs_w() as @mui_dll_dirs.
@auto_expand works with @mui_dll_dirs, but only affects the processed string, making it somewhat useless. The unprocessed string is always expanded internally, if its type is `REG_EXPAND_SZ` - there is no need to enable @auto_expand for this to work.
The API for this function changed in GLib 2.66 to add the @mui_dll_dirs argument.
Since: 2.66

parameter.name: mui_dll_dirs
parameter.parameter_description: a %NULL-terminated array of directory names where the OS should look for a DLL indicated in a MUI string, if the DLL path in the string is not absolute

parameter.name: auto_expand
parameter.parameter_description: (in) %TRUE to automatically expand G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_EXPAND_STR to G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_STR.

parameter.name: value_name
parameter.parameter_description: name of the value to get (in UTF-16). Empty string means the '(Default)' value.

parameter.name: value_data_size
parameter.parameter_description: size of the buffer pointed by @value_data, in bytes.

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure.

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_has_changed
function.description:
Check the @key's status indicator.
Since: 2.46
function.return: %TRUE if the @key was put under watch at some point and has changed since then, %FALSE if it either wasn't changed or wasn't watched at all.

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_new
function.description: Creates an object that represents a registry key specified by @path. @path must start with one of the following pre-defined names: - HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT - HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG - HKEY_CURRENT_USER - HKEY_CURRENT_USER_LOCAL_SETTINGS - HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_NLSTEXT - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_TEXT - HKEY_USERS @path must not end with '\\'.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: absolute full name of a key to open (in UTF-8)

function.return: a #GWin32RegistryKey or %NULL if can't be opened. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_new_w
function.description: Creates an object that represents a registry key specified by @path. @path must start with one of the following pre-defined names: - HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT - HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG - HKEY_CURRENT_USER - HKEY_CURRENT_USER_LOCAL_SETTINGS - HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_NLSTEXT - HKEY_PERFORMANCE_TEXT - HKEY_USERS @path must not end with L'\\'.

parameter.name: path
parameter.parameter_description: absolute full name of a key to open (in UTF-16)

function.return: a #GWin32RegistryKey or %NULL if can't be opened. Free with g_object_unref().

function.name: g_win32_registry_key_watch
function.description:
Puts @key under a watch.
When the key changes, an APC will be queued in the current thread. The APC will run when the current thread enters alertable state (GLib main loop should do that; if you are not using it, see MSDN documentation for W32API calls that put thread into alertable state). When it runs, it will atomically switch an indicator in the @key. If a callback was specified, it is invoked at that point. Subsequent calls to g_win32_registry_key_has_changed() will return %TRUE, and the callback (if it was specified) will not be invoked anymore. Calling g_win32_registry_key_erase_change_indicator() will reset the indicator, and g_win32_registry_key_has_changed() will start returning %FALSE. To resume the watch, call g_win32_registry_key_watch_for_changes() again.
Calling g_win32_registry_key_watch_for_changes() for a key that is already being watched is allowed and affects nothing.
The fact that the key is being watched will be used internally to update key path (if it changes).
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: watch_children
parameter.parameter_description: (in) %TRUE also watch the children of the @key, %FALSE to watch the key only.

parameter.name: watch_flags
parameter.parameter_description: specifies the types of changes to watch for.

parameter.name: callback
parameter.parameter_description: a function to invoke when a change occurs.

parameter.name: user_data
parameter.parameter_description: a pointer to pass to @callback on invocation.

function.return: %TRUE on success, %FALSE on failure.

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_assign
function.description:
Assigns the value of @other to @iter. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be assigned with `GWin32RegistrySubkeyIter i = j;`. The function is used by language bindings.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_clear
function.description:
Frees internal buffers of a #GWin32RegistrySubkeyIter.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_copy
function.description:
Creates a dynamically-allocated copy of an iterator. Dynamically-allocated state of the iterator is duplicated too.
Since: 2.46
function.return: a copy of the @iter, free with g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_free ()

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_free
function.description:
Free an iterator allocated on the heap. For iterators that are allocated on the stack use g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_clear () instead.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_get_name
function.description:
Gets the name of the subkey at the @iter potision.
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: subkey_name
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the name of a subkey (in UTF-8). Free with g_free().

parameter.name: subkey_name_len
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the length of @subkey_name, in gchars, excluding NUL-terminator. %NULL if length is not needed.

function.return: %TRUE if the name was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_get_name_w
function.description:
Same as g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_get_next(), but outputs UTF-16-encoded data, without converting it to UTF-8 first.
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: subkey_name
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the name of a subkey (in UTF-16).

parameter.name: subkey_name_len
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the length of @subkey_name, in gunichar2s, excluding NUL-terminator. %NULL if length is not needed.

function.return: %TRUE if the name was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_init
function.description:
Initialises (without allocating) a #GWin32RegistrySubkeyIter. @iter may be completely uninitialised prior to this call; its old value is ignored.
The iterator remains valid for as long as @key exists. Clean up its internal buffers with a call to g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_clear() when done.
Since: 2.46
function.return: %TRUE if iterator was initialized successfully, %FALSE on error.

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_n_subkeys
function.description:
Queries the number of subkeys items in the key that we are iterating over. This is the total number of subkeys -- not the number of items remaining.
This information is accurate at the point of iterator initialization, and may go out of sync with reality even while subkeys are enumerated.
Since: 2.46
function.return: the number of subkeys in the key

function.name: g_win32_registry_subkey_iter_next

parameter.name: skip_errors
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if iterator should silently ignore errors (such as the actual number of subkeys being less than expected) and proceed forward

function.return: %TRUE if next subkey info was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_assign
function.description:
Assigns the value of @other to @iter. This function is not useful in applications, because iterators can be assigned with `GWin32RegistryValueIter i = j;`. The function is used by language bindings.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_clear
function.description:
Frees internal buffers of a #GWin32RegistryValueIter.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_copy
function.description:
Creates a dynamically-allocated copy of an iterator. Dynamically-allocated state of the iterator is duplicated too.
Since: 2.46
function.return: a copy of the @iter, free with g_win32_registry_value_iter_free ().

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_free
function.description:
Free an iterator allocated on the heap. For iterators that are allocated on the stack use g_win32_registry_value_iter_clear () instead.
Since: 2.46

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_get_data
function.description:
Stores the data of the value currently being iterated over in @value_data, and its length - in @value_data_len (if not %NULL).
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: auto_expand
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to automatically expand G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_EXPAND_STR to G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_STR

parameter.name: value_data
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the data of the value (in UTF-8, if it's a string)

parameter.name: value_data_size
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the length of @value_data, in bytes (including any NUL-terminators, if it's a string). %NULL if length is not needed

function.return: %TRUE if value data was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_get_data_w
function.description:
Stores the data of the value currently being iterated over in @value_data, and its length - in @value_data_len (if not %NULL).
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: auto_expand
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE to automatically expand G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_EXPAND_STR to G_WIN32_REGISTRY_VALUE_STR

parameter.name: value_data
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the data of the value (in UTF-16, if it's a string)

parameter.name: value_data_size
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the size of @value_data, in bytes (including any NUL-terminators, if it's a string). %NULL if length is not needed.

function.return: %TRUE if value data was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_get_name
function.description:
Stores the name of the value currently being iterated over in @value_name, and its length - in @value_name_len (if not %NULL).
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: value_name
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the name of a value (in UTF-8).

parameter.name: value_name_len
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the length of @value_name, in gchars, excluding NUL-terminator. %NULL if length is not needed.

function.return: %TRUE if value name was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_get_name_w
function.description:
Stores the name of the value currently being iterated over in @value_name, and its length - in @value_name (if not %NULL).
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: value_name
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the name of a value (in UTF-16).

parameter.name: value_name_len
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the length of @value_name, in gunichar2s, excluding NUL-terminator. %NULL if length is not needed.

function.return: %TRUE if value name was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_get_value_type
function.description:
Stores the type of the value currently being iterated over in @value_type.
Since: 2.46

parameter.name: value_type
parameter.parameter_description: Pointer to a location to store the type of the value.

function.return: %TRUE if value type was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_init
function.description:
Initialises (without allocating) a #GWin32RegistryValueIter. @iter may be completely uninitialised prior to this call; its old value is ignored.
The iterator remains valid for as long as @key exists. Clean up its internal buffers with a call to g_win32_registry_value_iter_clear() when done.
Since: 2.46
function.return: %TRUE if iterator was initialized successfully, %FALSE on error.

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_n_values
function.description:
Queries the number of values items in the key that we are iterating over. This is the total number of values -- not the number of items remaining.
This information is accurate at the point of iterator initialization, and may go out of sync with reality even while values are enumerated.
Since: 2.46
function.return: the number of values in the key

function.name: g_win32_registry_value_iter_next

parameter.name: skip_errors
parameter.parameter_description: %TRUE if iterator should silently ignore errors (such as the actual number of values being less than expected) and proceed forward

function.return: %TRUE if next value info was retrieved, %FALSE otherwise.

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_get_file_info
function.description:
Gets the [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:file-info] property.
Since: 2.26
function.return: file info for the gzip header, if set

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_get_os
function.description:
Gets the [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:os] property.
Since: 2.86
function.return: the previously set OS value, or `-1` if unset

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_new
function.description:
Creates a compressor.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the format to use for the compressed data

function.return: a new [class@Gio.ZlibCompressor]

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_set_file_info
function.description:
Sets the [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:file-info] property.
Note: it is an error to call this function while a compression is in progress; it may only be called immediately after creation of @compressor, or after resetting it with [method@Gio.Converter.reset].
Since: 2.26

parameter.name: file_info
parameter.parameter_description: file info for the gzip header

function.name: g_zlib_compressor_set_os
function.description:
Sets the [property@Gio.ZlibCompressor:os] property.
Note: it is an error to call this function while a compression is in progress; it may only be called immediately after creation of @compressor, or after resetting it with [method@Gio.Converter.reset].
Since: 2.86

parameter.name: os
parameter.parameter_description: the OS code to use, or `-1` to unset

function.name: g_zlib_decompressor_get_file_info
function.description:
Gets the [property@Gio.ZlibDecompressor:file-info] property.
Since: 2.26
function.return: file info from the gzip header, if available

function.name: g_zlib_decompressor_new
function.description:
Creates a new decompressor.
Since: 2.24

parameter.name: format
parameter.parameter_description: the format to use for the compressed data

function.return: a new [class@Gio.ZlibDecompressor]

function.name: get_viewable_logical_drives
function.description: Returns the list of logical and viewable drives as defined by GetLogicalDrives() and the registry keys Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\Explorer under HKLM or HKCU. If neither key exists the result of GetLogicalDrives() is returned.
function.return: bitmask with same meaning as returned by GetLogicalDrives()
